text: A tall, handsome man in a dark suit emerges from a Lincol Towncar and enters a small, basement R&B/Jazz club.
He approaches a booth, says something in the din to the m there, then calmly shoots them and exits.

Bumpy Johnson, an elderly but still sturdy black man, elegantly dressed - cashmere overcoat, gloves, Homburg - stands in falling snow atop a flatbed truck - as he does every Thanksgiving - tossing down turkeys to the poor - like a benign king. Legend:   Harlem A younger man, the gunman from the club - Frank Lucas - Bumpy's driver/bodyguard/collector/protege - watches from below.
Whispering gunfire from a television set veiled by foreground snow: Soldiers in the jungles of Vietnam in 1970. A rich, cultured, authoritative voice offers:
This is the problem. This is what's wrong with America. The war footage multiplies by twenty: a stack of TVs with price tags dangling from the knobs behind a display windo
It's gotten so big you can't find your way. People on the sidewalk, out of respect or fear, part to l Frank and Bumpy and Bumpy's German shepherd pass.
The corner grocery's a supermarket. Candy store's a MacDonald's. And this place.

Where's the pride of ownership here? Where's the personal service? Does anybody work here? Inside, the emporium is vast, with aisles that seem to stretch off into infinity. The TVs give way to a display window full of Japanese stereo componentry.

What right do they have cutting out the suppliers, pushing all the middlemen out, buying direct from the manufacturer - Sony this, Toshiba that, all them Chinks - putting Americans out of work? He's not really asking Frank, so Frank doesn't answer.
What am I supposed to do with a place like this, Frank? Who am I supposed to ask for, the assistant manager? (pause)

This is the problem. This is the way it is now: You can't find the heart of anything to stick the knife. Bumpy stops before a display of cameras and stares in. They're all pointed at him as a pain grips his chest and sinks to his knees. Frank kneels down.
What is it? Bumpy seems unable to speak, looks to Frank confused.

Somebody call an ambulance! But the store suddenly seems empty. Frank yells into the emporium but can't be heard above the Muzak and the cash registers ringing up sales Bumpy will never see a piece o Looking up at Frank, Bumpy manages weakly -
Forget it, Frank. No one's in charge.

Limousines from the funeral disgorge mourners: family, friends, celebrities, politicians. Cops on horseback move through the enormous crowd that has gathered to watch. FB agents in cars snap pictures with long lenses of Italian mobsters like Albert Tosca.

- whose passing has brought together a who's who of mourners on this chilly afternoon. The Governor has come down. The mayor of New York - its Chief of Police and Commissioner - sports and entertainment luminaries - A white Bentley pulls up, disgorging Jackie Fox - the original Superfly - and his entourage. With his trademark tinted Gucci glasses on, he happily poses for anyone with camera - including the Feds - before going inside.
The report continues on a TV no one's really watching her a March of Time-like history of Bumpy Johnson, famed Harl gangster, Robin Hood and killer.

He was a Great Man, according to the eulogies. A giving man. A man of the people. No one chose to include in their remembrances the word most often associated with Ellsworth Bumpy Johnson: Gangster. Sitting off by himself in Bumpy's elegant garden apartmen heretofore his private sanctuary, Frank surveys the mourn circling the place like vultures: Tango Black, a huge brute, scavenging the catered food an tended bar ... Jackie Fox, surrounded by his ever-present coterie of sycophants ... Albert Tosca, an elegant Italia capo, and an underling, Rossi, at the bar.
White wine, please. A white man who looks like a banker - and is - sits down next to Frank.
How you doing, Frank?
All right.
What a loss. (Frank nods)
How are you otherwise?   Things okay financially?
Frank doesn't say. It feels unseemly to him to be talking about money here. He watches Tango carelessly set a water glass of ice on an antique inlaid chess table.
Bumpy set something up for you? Frank excuses himself without an answer, crosses to where Tango left the glass, and sets it on a coaster.

Hey, Frank, get me an ashtray while you're at it. Bumpy's German shepherd watches as Frank reaches into his jacket, revealing a gun nestled in its shoulder holster. takes out a handkerchief, wipes the condensation dry, ope a drawer and removes an ashtray. He holds it out to Tango who isn't sure it's not a dare and decides to wander off.
I know you're hurting, Frank.    So am I. Frank sits back down with Charlie Williams, an older dope man.
You going to be all right?
Yeah.
I'm sure Bumpy never told you, but he made me promise, anything ever happened to him, I'd make sure you didn't go without.
I'll be fine, Charlie. Half the people here owed Bumpy money when he died. A lot of money. If they think I'm going to forget to collect, they're wrong.
That's the spirit. Go get them. On the TV, over archive film and photographs of crime figures from the 1940's and `50's, the opinion is offered that Bumpy's death "marks the end of an era ..."
A figure, his back to us, walks slowly toward a blackboar like a man to the gallows.
I live in fear of hearing my name called.
Mr. Roberts, Give us U.S. vs. Meade -
Of walking up there, turning around, knowing every one of them knows more than I do -
Subject, issues, what the determination was and what it means to us today. Richie Roberts turns and faces his classmates, all of the decade or more younger than him.
Harlem's jagged teeth skyline juts across the river at th other end of the George Washington Bridge. On this side - sledgehammer gripped in Richie's fist, on the move, sudde fills the frame.
You know the Number 1 fear of most people isn't dying; it's public speaking. They get physically ill. They throw up.
And that's what you want to do for a living.

I don't like being like that.     I want to beat it. Armed with the sledgehammer, Richie and his partner - Jav Rivera - come past a seedy motel office where a TV shows another report about Bumpy Johnson. Legend:   New Jersey A motel clerk looks up, glimpses the sledgehammer -
Hey - Rivera flashes a New Jersey detective's shield without breaking stride. Takes a subpoena out of another pocket.
Who's going to do this?
He knows me, he'll take it from me. I've known him since high school.

Just throw it in, he doesn't take it. That's good service. They reach a particular motel room door. Rivera knocks. The door opens the length of a chain, revealing a wise gu in an undershirt, who, when he sees the subpoena, start t close the door -

Throw it - As Richie flings the subpoena in, the door slams on his hand. He wails in agony, tries to shoulder it open, hears the dead bolt lock on the other side, feels Campizi's tee bite into his fingers, watches his blood run down the fra
Down - Richie hangs down from his hand as the sledgehammer swing past his head shattering the door -

The door rips from its hinges and the detectives crash in The wise guy - Campizi - hurries for the bathroom, slams door. This one's hollow and the detectives more easily break through it - Campizi tries to climb out the bathroom window. Richie grabs him, throws him into the shower stall, taking the plastic curtain down with them, smearing it with blood as Richie beats at him before Rivera can pull him off.
A male paramedic attends to Campizi's bloodied face while female paramedic cleans Richie's bloodied hand.
I swear to God, Richie, I didn't know it was you. I would never slam a door on your hand. Knowingly.
You bit my fuckin hand -
Richie lunges at him, hits him again with his injured han which hurts Richie more than it does Campizi. The paramedics manage to pull him away.
What can we do, Richie? You don't want to do this. For old times sake, what can we do? Who do you want? Who can I give you? You want Big Sal's bookie? You want his accountant? I'll give him to you.
Richie regards him a moment. A policy ring's accountant wouldn't be bad. He glances back to his paramedic dabbing at his bloody hand, and notices she's not bad-looking. Sh smiles back.
Four men in long black leather coats stride toward like they own the city. It's impossible to tell if they're cop or gangsters. Legend:   New York City

One of the same undercover cops - Detective Trupo - scribbles a signature and badge number different from the one on his gold shield lying next to the voucher requesti evidence needed in court. He pushes the voucher under a sign - "All Handguns and Narcotics Before 10am Next Window" - to a clerk who takes past floor-to-ceiling shelves covered with files, plastic bags bulging with handguns, knives and gambling receipts. Bulkier items - like shotguns and baseball bats - lie unwrapped with dangling tags. The clerk reaches a chain-link cage where the most valuab items are locked up - narcotics, pornography, cash - chec the voucher against tags, takes down an old green suitcas
Trupo's car - a Shelby Mustang - roars up. He climbs out, crosses to a warehouse with the suitcase as the other thr SIU Princes of the City follow from another car, cradling grocery bags.

Trupo snaps the suitcase open revealing five half-kilo ba of uncut heroin in clear plastic bags. The other cops pul from the grocery bags: a Pyrex mixing bowl, flour sifter, boxes of milk-sugar, latex kitchen gloves, a medical scal and yellow baggies. Hands peel back the distinctive black and green "evidence tape on the clear plastic bags. Dump the heroin into twen yellow baggies. A half-kilo of lactose is poured into eac of the now-empty property room bags.
Now just enough for the reagent test.

He removes one tablespoon of heroin from each of the baggies, and the now-almost-heroin-free powder is mixed through the flour sifter, poured back into the clear bags the tape resealed, the bags returned to the suitcase.

The suitcase and   "heroin," and some weapons and money, been arranged on   an evidence table with the care of a M display window.    Trupo - the officer in charge of the c watches the jury   files in -

A Lincoln Continental pulls up. Trupo climbs out of his Shelby with a sports bag, crosses to the Lincoln, climbs back where an Italian wise guy - Rossi - sits. Trupo unzi the bag revealing the recut heroin - in the yellow plasti
This is the French Connection dope. The same dope Popeye Doyle and Sonny Grasso took from us.
Frank comes into an empty bar, chairs up on tables. A middle-aged man mopping up glances up at him as he crosse to a back room.
They seize it, arrest everybody, whack it up and sell it back to us. Our dope. They been living off it for years, these New York cops.
Several ounces of the dope sits in foreground on a table.
They basically control the market with it. What the fuck has happened to the world, Frank?
Fuckin crooks. Rossi, who looks more like a middle-aged accountant than Italian dope supplier he is, makes two espressos.
Sad about Bumpy. Behind Frank, a TV airs a report by Walter Cronkite on th heroin problem among GIs in Vietnam.
Things are never going to be the same in Harlem. The girls, the clubs, the music - walk down the street, nobody bothers you because Bumpy's making sure of it. (hands Frank one of the espressos)

How bad is it there now? 18pt   FLASHCUTS TO HARLEM Guys barge into a room, steal money from a crap game at gunpoint - Cops push guys against a bar, empty their pock - A dealer shoots another dealer in an alley - 18pt   BACK TO THE HOTEL ROOM
It's chaos.    Every gorilla for himself.
18pt   CONTINUED:
Who can live like that? There has to be order. That would never happen with Italians. More important than any one man's life - is order.
A street sign on a corner:        116th and 8th Avenue.
As is his custom, Frank eats breakfast alone. A middle- aged waitress appears when he's done, picks up his plate and refills his coffee.
Thank you, Charlene.      Last one.
It's all right with me, Frank, you can stay all day if you want, but I wouldn't. It's nice outside.
Then maybe I'll have to go for a walk. Just cause you said so.
She smiles and leaves. Frank pours some sugar in his coffee. Someone taps on the window and he looks up, sees two servicemen - one in uniform - one he recognizes.
Frank leads the servicemen up the stairs of a building.

Corner apartment above the street. A girl sits smoking at a work table covered with drug-cutting apparatus. Another Frank's cutter and sometimes-girlfriend, Red Top - sets a couple of packets of heroin in front of the servicemen.
On the house for our men in uniform.
Why, thank you, sugar, that's very kind.
Thank Frank.
Frank nods, you're welcome before the man can thank him. The servicemen start cooking up the dope.
How's Nate?   You seen him?
All the time. Nate is everywhere. He's good. Got himself a club now.
Where, Saigon?
Bangkok.
I don't think he's ever coming home.
Regarding the dope as the servicemen shoot it up -
You're gonna have to boot it a couple times. Cops keep cutting it, selling it, cutting it -
I don't want to say anything cause the price is right - but the shit in Nam is way, way, way, way, way -
He begins to nod out before he can finish the sentence.
Across the river, Richie, Rivera and Campizi sit in the c parked across from a closed social club. A man carrying a grocery bag comes out and Campizi ducks lower in the seat
That's him.
Newsboy Moriarty's mob accountant puts the grocery bag in the trunk of a car, climbs in behind the wheel.
From the parked car they observe the accountant putting another bag in his trunk.
He comes out of another place with another bag.       To
All right.   Get lost.    Get out. Campizi slinks out of the car. Richie and Rivera follow after Newsboy Moriarty's accountant's car.
They tail the car into a lot, park and watch the accounta leave his car and get into another car that's parked ther RIVERA
We gonna stay with him or the car? Whatever they do, they'll have to decide quick. RICHIE
Let's see who comes for the car.
All the other cars are gone. Rivera climbs into Richie's with coffee and a Coke in a bag, hands him the can. RIVERA
Think he made us? Richie doesn't know. Glances at his watch.      Cranes in seat to look behind them. RICHIE
You called for the warrant?     Where are they? RIVERA
I just called. I called and walked back here and ten seconds has gone by. Richie watches an attendant lock up, listens to the stree lamps buzz, grows impatient. Indicating the other car: RICHIE
We saw him with the slips, Javy. RIVERA
You saw policy slips? You saw grocery bags. You don't know what's in them.
Yes, I do, and so do you, don't give me that bullshit -
What's the rush? Half an hour the warrant'll be here -
I got night school.

Guess you're going to miss it. (Rivera sips at his coffee;                            then:)                                                You know, what you were saying before - about throwing up in front of people - money will take that feeling away.
Not when it's less.
Less than what.
Than what I make now.
No lawyer on earth makes less than a cop.
They do in the Prosecutor's Office. Three thousand less.
You're fuckin kidding me.
Richie isn't kidding. Rivera stares at him like he's craz Richie checks his watch. He's waited long enough.
Fuck this -
Richie -

Richie gets out, opens the trunk, grabs a Slimjim and bolt cutters, cuts through a gate chain and strides to th accountant's car, Rivera following. Richie trips the passenger door lock and pulls at the trunk release, and, he comes around back to search it -
Check inside.
Rivera may as well; the damage to the case, if there is o anymore, is done. He crawls inside the car to look under the seats and in the glove compartment. Gravely -
Javy ...

Richie's staring into the trunk like there's a body insid Rivera comes over, takes a look, sees it's money: stacks it rubber-banded together, spilling from grocery bags - m than either of them has ever seen. As the trunk closes -
Richie and Rivera sit in their car in silence, staring ou at the car with the money in it. Eventually -
This isn't a couple of bucks.
It's the same thing.   In principle.
We're talking about principle?
Richie, a cop who turns in this kind of money says one thing: He'll turn in cops who take money. We'll be pariahs.
We're fucked either way.
Not if we keep it. Only if we don't. Then we're fucked, you're right. But not if we keep it.
(more to himself) Yes, we are.
Goddamn it, did we ask for this? Did we put a gun to someone's head and say, Give us your money? Cops kill cops they can't                  trust. We can't turn it in.
They regard each other again in silence ...

As a police captain counts the stacks of money, Lou Tobac Richie's superior from the prosecutors office, walks in, night out interrupted by this emergency. He crossed to wh Richie and Rivera sit alone in a corner. Quietly: TOBACK
How much. RICHIE
Nine hundred and eighty thousand. TOBACK

What happened to the rest? It's a joke but isn't funny, not even to Toback. He regar his men who turned it in, then the other cops in the plac who are watching them and the money being counted. Toback walks over to the captain, and, quietly: TOBACK
What're you doing counting this in front of everybody? Are you out of your fuckin mind? Take it into a room. Now. Richie's glance to Rivera says, You're right, we're fucke

As Richie leaves alone, he's aware of all the eyes on him knowing the other cops' looks don't signify awe or respec but contempt and fear, like Rivera predicted. Neither wil ever be trusted again. He climbs into his car, drives off
Tango and his bodyguard come in and approach Frank's tabl where he reads the morning paper as he eats breakfast. TANGO
Didn't you see the jar, Frank? I think you walked right past it. Frank ignores him, forks at his eggs, eats.    Tango sits TANGO

The money jar. On the corner.      What I got to do, put a sign on it? Frank indicates that he would answer if his mouth wasn't full. He swallows finally, but then only reaches for his coffee cup to take a sip, further irritating Tango.
Bumpy don't own 116th Street no more, Frank. Bumpy don't own no real estate in Harlem no more. I'm the landlord now and the lease is twenty-percent.
Frank dabs at his mouth with a napkin and gives Tango a l that says that won't be happening.
Then don't sell dope, Frank. Get a fuckin job. You need a job? You can be my driver, drive me around, open my door, yes, sir, no sir, where to, sir, right away, Massa Johnson, sir.
Right now Tango is dead. No doubt about it.          On t surface, though, Frank remains cool.
Twenty percent?
Of every dollar. Every VIG, every truckload, every girl, every ounce.      In the jar.

Twenty percent's my profit. If I'm giving it to you then what am I doing? Twenty percent puts me, and everyone you know, out of business, which puts you out of business. (reaches for his breakfast check) There are ways to make money legitimately, and then there's this way. Not even Bumpy took twenty percent.
Bumpy's fuckin dead.
Frank regards Tango a moment, gets up, takes out his mone clip, covers the check on the table with a five, peels of $1 bill from the clip, tosses it down in front of Tango.
There.   That's twenty-percent.
As he turns and leaves, Tango watches after him ...
Stitched-up, black and blue hands dump a can of soup in a pot, put it on the stove.

A pencil clutched by long fingers scribbles figures. But no matter how many times Frank does the arithmetic, there not much left, he calculates, after he pays the Italian suppliers and, if he were to, Tango.

Richie has moved to a small desk cluttered with law textbooks. He cracks one open to study for the New Jersey Bar exam as he eats the soup out of the pot he heated it Above him on the wall is a framed photograph of Joe Louis standing over a sprawled-on-the-mat Billy Conn.
A bleak day. Seagulls fighting over scraps on the sand as others hover overhead, flapping and cawing. Alone near th water, Frank tosses a stick for the German shepherd he inherited.
Richie opens a small wooden box in his bleak apartment, revealing an ounce of marijuana, rolling papers and clips As he rolls a joint - BUMPY V/O
A leader is like a shepherd -
The sounds of the gulls and surf and roller coaster begin fade as Frank throws the stick again. BUMPY V/O

Sends the fast nimble sheep out front, and the others follow as the shepherd walks quietly behind - The dog retrieves the stick, but this time - somehow - it to Bumpy's hand he returns it. Frank listens attentively. BUMPY
He's got the stick - the cane - and he'll use if he has to. (MORE)
But most of the time he doesn't have to. He moves the whole herd - quietly.
Bumpy smiles and tosses the stick.
The smoke from the joint rises to the ceiling as Richie studies.
The dog trots back to Bumpy and Frank with the stick.
Hot dog stand. Bumpy hands a hot dog to Frank, holds out another to the shepherd. To camera:
What right do they have cutting out the suppliers, the middlemen, buying direct, putting Americans out of work ... This is the way it is now, Frank.

Frank nods. The vender hands him a napkin. The shepherd is still with him, but Bumpy is gone, and the gulls and t people on the roller coaster squeal as Frank comes out of his meditative trance with an idea.
A needle pierces the crook of Frank's arm.       Slight g A cotton ball is pushed onto the puncture.       Malaria
A strobe lights up Frank's face:      a passport photo.
The photo and a duplicate are stapled to a passport application.
Keys turn the locks of a safety-deposit box. The lid lift revealing decks of cash. Frank takes it all out, slips on slender packet into Bumpy's banker's jacket pocket.
Get yourself a new suit.
Under portraits of bank Vice Presidents before him, the m types out a Chemical Bank check for Frank for $400,000.
The sound of the plane growls and fades overhead as Richi ex-wife keeps an eye on their son playing on a grassy are
I'm sorry.
I don't know, Richie.
It couldn't be avoided. Next weekend I'll be able to take him.
She regards him with a weary look, but he's looking over one of the other - better-looking - moms in the park.
I'm moving.
He looks back, not sure he heard right.
What?   Where?
To the St. Regis, what do you care. (pause) My sister's.
Your sister's. In Vegas?
He glances away to a sound: shattering glass.        Some agers breaking bottles on the ground.
You can't move to Vegas.     Not with Michael anyway.
What am I supposed to do with him?       Leave him with you? There's a picture.
(to the vandals) Hey, you want to shut up over there?
The teenagers ignore him. He tries to ignore them, but it hard with the constant noise.
No court will allow it for one thing. I won't allow it.
You?
When am I supposed to see my son?
Last weekend!
Their son glances over at them. Richie looks over at the teenagers again breaking bottles, then back to Laurie.
Laurie, you can't raise a kid in Las Vegas.
Oh, like this is a good environment. Around your friends. There are less creeps in Vegas.
What's he going to grow up to be in a mobbed up place like that? What are you thinking?
I'm thinking - Richie - of him!
Goddamn it -
The noise of the glass is driving him crazy. He strides over to the teenagers, who look at him like, What are you gonna do, old man, it's four against one.
I told you nice to shut the fuck up. Now I'm gonna kill you.
He pulls out his gun and aims it at one of them, then the others. All instinctively try to cover their heads.
Pick up the fuckin glass!
As they dive to their knees to do what they're told, Laur walks away with her son, who looks back over his shoulder his father with his gun out.
Frank sits in the back of a motor samlor.       Bicycles around it like flies.

The clientele is almost exclusively black servicemen on R and Asian women. A trio of ex-GI's plays authentic Southe blues on a small stage. Ham hocks and collard greens come out of the kitchen. Smoke chokes the place. Frank, one of the few men not in uniform, and not drunk o stoned, sits alone at a table with a Coca-Cola and survey the activity: Dope being rolled. Dope being smoked. Dope being shot. GI's and prostitutes climbing a staircase. His eyes follow an Army Master Sergeant, moving among the tables as if checking on the GI's well being. But at some his hand takes money, leaves in its place packets of powd The Sergeant feels eyes on him and glances up, catching Frank watching him from across the room. He squints throu the smoke at the figure at the table in the shadows, and, a kind of shock, more to himself -
Frank - ?
Frank half-lifts his glass to wave, and Nate beams.
Frank has guests at his table now: his cousin Nate the Sergeant, and two young Asian wise guys. They talk about him in Thai (subtitled):
He say how much he wants?
He said "a lot." What that means, I don't know. Four or five keys?
The Thais regard Frank a moment, size him up.
He's your cousin.
My cousin-in-law.    My ex-wife's cousin.
Ask him how much he wants.
How much you gonna want, Frank?
A hundred kilos.
Nate blinks like there's something in his eye ...
Steam and neon.    Frank and Nate at a crowded stand.
No one I know can get that much. It'd have to be pieced together from several suppliers and none of it's gonna be 100- percent pure.
That's not what I want.
I know that. But that means dealing with the Chiu-Chou syndicates in Cholon or Saigon - if they'll deal with you -
No, even then it's too late. It's been chopped. I want to get it where they get it. From the source.
Nate stares at him ... then laughs.       Frank doesn't.
You're gonna go get it.
Why not.
You're gonna go into the fuckin jungle -
I've lived in jungles all my (life) -
No. This is the jungle. Tigers. Vietcong. The fuckin snakes alone will kill you.

location: NEW JERSEY BOARD OF BAR EXAMINERS

text: A room of student-type desks and no character. Richie, and fifty others, have been here for hours taking the exa less than half of them will pass.

A motley bunch of Thai thugs and black American soldiers with automatic weapons ride mules through the dense jungl with Nate and Frank, who - armed with a pistol, a rifle a ammo bandolier like Pancho Villa - is enjoying himself. From his POV, the jungle canopy suddenly opens up on a po field the size of Manhattan. Frank stares down at it.
On the ground now with their small private army, Nate spe with one of the Thais, then translates for Frank.
He says this whole area's controlled by the Kuomintang - Chiang Kai-Shek's defeated army.
Some of whom they can see down below on the opium farm - Chinese soldiers with outdated weapons. Frank tips his he to Nate at some other figures below -
They ain't Chinese.
A handful of better-armed American sentries at the perime of the farm. CIA. Frank, Nate and the others hang back as one of the Thais steps ahead to speak to the guerillas.

The processing center for the entire region. The Thai translator is with Frank to negotiate with a vanquished Chinese general. Other Americans and Thais guard them while the Chinese with their CIA advisors guard them.
The Chinese general examines Frank's papers - passport, visa, bank receipts - and lots of cash - then studies Fra
How would you get it into the States?
What do you care?
Who do you work for in there?
What do you care?
Who are you really?
It says right there.   Frank Lucas.
I mean, who you represent?
Me. The man doesn't believe it, but lets it go.

You think you're going to take a hundred kilos of heroin into the US and you don't work for anyone? Someone is going to allow that? Frank shrugs. The general regards one of his men.       I Chinese, subtitled:
I don't believe a word of this. The general regards the cash and paperwork again for a moment. And, to Frank:
After this first purchase, if you're not killed by Marseilles importers - or their people in the States - then what?
Then there'd be more. On a regular basis. Though I'd rather not have to drag my ass all the way up here every time.
The man regards Frank for a long moment.       Glances ba the cash and paperwork again. Finally -
Of course not.
Torrential monsoon rains. Dripping camouflage. Nate and Frank climb down from the Huey. Frank no longer wears the bandolier. Now a press card dangles from his neck.

head_text.subj: F56 INT/EXT. TENT / JUNGLE ARMY LZ

text: Stripes on the uniform of a black colonel with Nate under canopy. Outside, in the distance, in the rain, Frank hang out with some other black servicemen.
Where's it now?
Bangkok. I can bring it here or anywhere in between.
A hundred kilos. (Nate nods) I never seen that much dope in one place.
It's bigger than an Amana refrigerator- freezer.
Nate and Frank watch the colonel emerge from the tent and cross through the rain on duck-boards to another tent to speak with a white officer, a 2-star general.
Fifty grand. In advance. That'll cover them, the pilots and the guys on the other end.
Give them a hundred.
Fifty, to cover them all.
A hundred. And it's all I got left. So if that dope doesn't arrive, for whatever reason - (embraces Nate and whispers) Cousin or no cousin - don't let me down.
He holds out a business envelope fat with money. Nate hesitates, knowing Frank has just said he'll kill him if things don't go right, then takes it.
I'll let you know when it's in the air.

The nurse/paramedic who stitched up his hand is in Richie bed making so much noise he's worried someone will call t cops. The phone rings. And won't stop. Neither will the nurse as Richie answers it -
Richie? Richie, I'm in trouble.    This fuckin guy "made" me - I don't know how but he did. He went for his gun. I had to do it, I swear to God. Now they're going to kill me.
Richie can hear in Sander's voice how serious it is and manages to disentangle himself from the woman.
Who.
There's a hundred people out there heard the shots. You gotta help me. You gotta do something.
Is he dead?
He's dead.    I'm dead. They're gonna kill me.
Where are you? Javy, where are you?
That's the problem.
Richie on his police radio, which cuts in and out -
There are no cars in that area, Detective Roberts.
Bullshit. I got a man in trouble and I need back-up.
I missed that - you're breaking up -
I said, put the fucking call out again -
I just did. No one responded.     I'll try again, but -
Fuck you, too.
He slams the mic down.

As Richie's car turns a corner, the Stephen Crane Project the most foreboding place on earth - rises up: three dark 30-floor towers planted on war-torn grounds where a long- torched and abandoned patrol car sits like a monument. Dial tone: the police sergeant has hung up on him. throws the phone. The paramedics stare at him.

The only other person who would know the answer to that i Rivera, who just shakes his head in despair.
Bandage his head.
Detective ... he's dead.
I know he's fucking dead. Bandage his head, clean him up, put him on a gurney and prop it up so he's sitting. And open his eyes.
Richie comes out ahead of the gurney, moving quickly like it's a matter of life and death (which it is), motioning the crowd to allow a path to the ambulance.

What?   What are you talking about?

This.   Where'd this come from?
What. That's my money. I've never taken dirty money in my life.
You lying piece of shit -

Yeah.
No, it isn't. It's part of the salary for getting shot at. For that, certain courtesies are shown. In gratitude -
Richie, disgusted with him, lets go of him.         River embarrassed, almost crying, pleading -
A discount on a TV, a Doughboy in the backyard, a new dress for your girlfriend maybe once a year. I'm talking about not living in fucking poverty. You want to call that wrong, call it wrong.
It's wrong.

Then goddamn it, pay me fifty grand a year, you son of a bitch. Pay me what I deserve for getting shot at. No? Fine. Next time four guys come into your place with sawed-off shotguns, you take care of it.

I'm a leper. Because I listened to you and turned in a million fucking dollars. You know who'll work with me after that? Same as you. No one.

Don't look down there. Look here. (at Richie's eyes) You ever fuckin threaten me again, I'll kill you.

Open the trunk.

The duffel bags, still closed, on a table. Frank regards them, nursing a drink, putting off the moment of discover that he has perhaps spent his life's savings on nothing.

The German shepherd watches as Frank removes the tape fro one of the bags. Take it with you. I don't want to have to call the coroner.
The chemist gathers his things to leave, offering a last piece of advice -
Store it in a cool, dark place.

A clapboard house set down on a piece of land that was probably once worked by sharecroppers. An elderly woman framed in a lit kitchen window, doing dishes. Yeah.

Frank.

Frank your brother.

All rise -

Frank and the dog in the back yard of a suburban house. His neighbors - those he can see - are white. He got an arm on him.     Major League arm, ain't that right.
Everyone agrees as Turner's son - Frank's nephew - the 18 year-old boy seen pitching in the North Carolina back yar tries to shrug.
You show me after supper.
You can't catch him. He'll take your head off. We're talking 95-mile-an-hour. You know how fast that is? You see the ball leave his hand, and that's the last you see it before it knocks you down.
(smiling; happy) Is that right.
The wonderful noise continues downstairs as Frank leads h mother on a tour of the upstairs. The place is a showroom of traditional Americana.
This is your room.

Mrs. Lucas is   in awe of the splendor of the bedroom and furnishings.    It's unlike anything she's used ever seen not Graceland   exactly - but not far off. Her eyes settl an old vanity   dotted with French perfume bottles.
How did you ...
I had it made. From memory.
You were five when they took it away. How could you remember it?
I remember.
She's stunned. Touches the reproduction of the vanity her son last saw more than thirty years ago.
It's perfect. (looks at the room) It's all perfect. (she looks at him) I'm so proud of you.
The Statue of Liberty against the New York skyline. FRANK V/O
The man I worked for ran one of the biggest companies in New York City for almost fifty years.
As Frank leads his brothers down the sidewalk, the Townca that was parked at the Teaneck house, driven by Frank's b guard, Doc, follows alongside at the same pace they walk. FRANK

I was with him every day for fifteen of them, looking after him, taking care of things, protecting him, learning from him. The brothers can't help but notice the storekeepers who w to Frank, the women who smile, the men who step out of hi path like there's a red carpet under his polished shoes. FRANK
Bumpy was rich, but never white   man rich. Why? Because he didn't own the    company. He thought he did. He didn't.     He only managed it. Someone else owned    it. So they owned him.
Frank leads his brothers up the stairs and down the hall. FRANK
Nobody owns me. Because I own my company. INTERCUT: Feminine hands stamp small packets of blue cellophane with the words `Blue Magic' - FRANK
And my company sells a product that's better than the competition's at a price that's lower. Frank stops outside an apartment door. TEDDY
What are we selling, Frank?
Frank pushes the door open, revealing -

Five naked women at work tables, their faces veiled by surgical masks, cutting heroin with lactose and quinine i precise mixture of controlled purity. The Lucas brothers stare as the supervisor of the activity - clothed, with r hair - comes over.

Tango strolls down the street like he's the Godfather of Harlem, girl on his arm, bodyguard at his side.

What matters in business is honesty, integrity, hard work, loyalty, and never forgetting where you came from.
For reasons his brothers can't imagine, Frank empties all sugar from the container onto his plate.
You are what you are and that's one of two things. You're nothing ... or you're something. Understand what I'm saying?
The brothers nod tentatively, stare at the now-empty glas container. Frank wipes his mouth with a napkin, gets up.
I'll be right back.
He comes out of the diner, crosses the street toward Tang who's buying fruit. Greets him cheerfully -
Hey, Tango, what's up.    I was just thinking about you.
I was looking at the jar and you know what? I didn't    see nothing in it.
The fuck you want, Frank -

Before the last word is out of Tango's mouth, Frank's got gun pressed against his forehead. Silence. Everyone backs away - the bodyguard, too. Tango's girl pulls her arm fro his and takes off. Eventually -
What're you going to do, boy? Shoot me in broad daylight? In front of everyone?
It's as if life on the street has stopped. No one moves; everyone is looking at Frank; maybe that's what he wants. As Tango laughs at the thought -
Yeah, that's right.

Frank pulls the trigger and the big man falls back like someone hit with a board. Frank stands over him and empti the gun in his chest, the shots echoing down the street. Then it's quiet again. Everyone's still looking him, but Frank doesn't run. Instead, he calmly reaches into Tango' suit pocket, takes out a money clip thick with cash, drop it in the "jar" and sets it next to the body.
For the cops. Should be enough.

Frank returns to the diner and sits back down, ignoring t astonished stares from his brothers and everyone else in place. Tries to remember where he was in his lecture as h tucks the napkin back in his shirt collar.
That basically's the whole picture right there.
A cadaver drawer slides open revealing - not Tango - but Rivera, staring up lifeless, his arms, stomach, legs and toes dotted with the scabs of a longtime addict.
Did you know his girlfriend? Good- looking girl. One of his informants.
Beth.
The medical examiner slides open another cadaver drawer containing her body. Richie stares at it.
Should've seen their place.    Like animals lived there.
I have seen it.
(to the examiner) Chose a good night, huh?   Grand Central Station in here.

Heroin addiction is no longer exclusive to big city neighborhoods; it's epidemic -
The reports shows lawmakers on Capitol Hill juxtaposed against images of inner-cities, junkies, homicide victims and, perhaps most telling, white suburbia.

Since 1965, law enforcement has watched its steady increase and with it a rise in violent crime. Now unaccountably, it has exploded, reaching into cities as a whole - our suburbs and towns - our schools.
The TV is in a small police gym where Richie lifts weight very much aware of his pariah status as out-of-shape cops come in, only to leave again when they see him.

Someone is finally saying: enough. Federal authorities have announced their intention to establish special narcotics bureaus in Washington, New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, Boston, Newark and other major cities -
Toback comes in, watches Richie, alone, working out.
It's a dog and pony show.

Though he's not in much of a position to refuse the assignment, Richie still isn't convinced it's a good idea Toback levels with him -
Richie, a detective who doesn't have the cooperation of his fellow detectives can't be effective.

Doesn't matter.
No, they're all on the take and I'm not and it doesn't matter to anyone. Instead of giving you a medal for turning in money, they bury you.
It's fucked up. You're right. Maybe this's an opportunity away from all that.
They regard each other.    Eventually -
I'll do it, but only like this: I don't set foot in a police station again. I work out of a place of my own. And I pick my own guys. Guys I know wouldn't take a nickel off the sidewalk.
Done.

Richie regards the colored light thrown down by the stain glass windows -
Frank regards light streaming in from the garden terrace
Richie picks up a faded photograph of a priest in a broke frame. To the maintenance man:
This is the only floor we'll be using.
Frank distractedly opens and closes a 12' high curtain in one of the rooms -
No loan, no contingencies.    Cash sale.
Wet streets and neon. Well-dressed crowd behind a velvet rope outside the club. The Apollo in the background: Jame Brown on the marquee.

What is this?
He turns Teddy so he's facing a mirror.
What. These are clothes.     This is a very nice (suit) -
I'm wearing clothes. These are clothes. Those - (Teddy's in the mirror) - are a costume. With a sign on it that says Arrest me. You look like fuckin Jackie Fox.
What's wrong with Jackie.    I like Jackie.
You like Jackie? You want to be Superfly? Go work for him, end up in a cell with him.
Teddy pulls himself from Frank's grasp. Smooths his shirt adjusts his hat. Frank tries to explain to him:

He wants to talk to you by the way.     I told him I'd tell you.
Frank stares at his brother's reflection in the mirror.
You and Jackie were talking about me?
Not about you. We were talking. He said he wanted to talk to you about something.

I'm taking you shopping tomorrow.
I went shopping today.
You go shopping every day.    Like a girl.

How much you owe?
It's nothing, like - fifty grand.
Frank isn't sure if it's an honor or a curse to have a celebrity like Joe Louis asking to borrow money, but nods
Sure.   Don't worry about it.
Thank you.   I'll pay you back soon as -
Joe. It's a gift. Not a loan.       You don't owe me nothing.

Jackie glides into the club with his magazines and entourage. Frank comes into the coat check area where Doc waits with his overcoat. As Frank slips into it, Miss Puerto Rico - returning from the ladies room - comes through.
Hi.   I'm Ana.
I'm Frank.
You're Frank and this is your place. (he doesn't say whether it is or not) Why's it called Small's? Why don't you call it Frank's?

A club across the river. Not nearly as nice as Small's - much louder - but like Small's, almost all black. Richie shares a booth with a black undercover detective.

Ana waiting on a corner, dressed nice, handbag.         T pulls to the curb.

Outside the house, Doc sits in the car reading a newspape

You're right. He was as important as Dr. King, though.
What'd he do?
A lot of things. He had a lot of friends. He served New York and it served him.
What was he to you?
Frank has to think.     Bumpy was more than his employer.
Teacher.

The room explodes with a boom and the detective crumples the floor, clutching at his leg, blood running through hi fingers onto the carpet. Frank stares.

Oh, he's all right. I just shot him in the leg. You got a health plan, what are you complaining about. He's fine. Here - (peels off some money) Five hundred all right? Six? Look, he's feeling better all the time.
Suddenly, Frank grabs Jimmy and throws him against the wa
As Ana tries to clean the blood stain on the rug with sal and soda water, Frank sits with his five brothers in the debris-strewn aftermath of the party. Silence before:
I can't have this kind of stupidity.
It was an accident.   He feels terrible about it.
He doesn't feel shit, coked up all the time. Get rid of him.
Frank. He's your cousin. What's he gonna do? Go back home? I'll talk to him. I'll straighten him out.
Frank looks at Teddy in his tinted Jackie Fox-like goggle glasses - like he's going to straighten anybody out.
Gimme those glasses.
What?   Why?
Frank pulls them from Teddy's face and crushes them.

Richie sifts through the morning mail at his desk. Stops on an envelope from the New Jersey Bar Association. As he works up the nerve to open it, Spearman, Jones and Abruzz organize the Italian wise guys' photos on the T.O.
Ice Pick Paul goes here -
No, he's under Benny Two-Socks -
No, you're thinking of Benny the Bishop. Benny Two-Socks is Tosca's deadbeat son- in-law.
Jonesy's right.
Richie comes over, studies the Table of Organization a moment, then begins untacking the photos from the top dow
What're you doing?     We just -

For a cop the uppermost thing is the arrest. For a prosecutor, the arrest is nothing without the evidence to convict. We don't have any real evidence on anyone on this board, so they're coming down. We're starting over from the street.
What are you, a prosecutor all of a sudden?
Richie tacks his exam results onto the T.O.       He pass
Richie and the Amigos observe a buy from a parked car, th blue cellophane changing hands. Ignoring the buyer as he walks away, they keep watching the seller.

The seller is observed coming out of a mechanics garage. Richie ignores him as he walks away, watching instead the garage. Eventually, a mechanic wiping his hands on a rag steps out, and Richie raises a camera. The image of the mechanic - a supplier - freezes -
A slightly-blurred photo of the mechanic goes up on a new almost bare Table of Organization.
Atop of a telephone pole, Abruzzo, dripping with lineman equipment, works to attach a `slave' to the lines -
Bare room. Richie, Jones and Spearman eating take-out foo as tape recorder reels turn.
Those snow tires you give me last time come in yet? I'm going to want some more of them, gimme one and a half more of them.
The detectives laugh.
Toback has Richie sign a voucher for $20,000 cash.
This is more than a year's salary, Richie. If it disappears, I won't be able to get it for you again.
It'll never be out of my sight.
Jones tapes a tape recorder the size of a pack of cigaret to Richie's bare chest.
Undercover in a wise guy's cashmere sweater and slacks, Richie watches the mechanic count the $10,000 he's given him.
It's got to be `Blue Magic.'
Yeah, yeah, it's `Blue.' You can pick it up here tomorrow. Where's the rest of the money?
That's half. I'll give you the other half tomorrow when you give -
No, no, no, I don't do that.    Go fuck yourself.
Richie rather reluctantly hands over the rest of the 20K.

Spearman watches the pickup truck driven by the mechanic change lanes up ahead - heading for the George Washington Bridge - and glances over concerned to Richie, who is changing the cashmere sweater for an old t-shirt.
He's going into New York.   Are we?
What are they going to do, arrest us?
They could. New York cops.     They can do worse than that.
We're not losing that money.    Go.
As Spearman follows the truck, the George Washington Brid linking Jersey to Manhattan, looms in the windshield ...

The pickup pulls to the curb outside a Pleasant Avenue grocery store. As the guy enters the place, Spearman's ca stops long enough for Richie to climb out, and continues Richie crosses the street, tries to see who the guy is talking to inside, but he's just buying a cup of coffee t go. Spearman's car turns the corner to circle around the block. As soon as it's gone, the man emerges from the restaurant with the coffee and walks straight at Richie w has to double back quickly not to be seen Richie sees a delivery truck double-parked, guys unloadin crates. Hears a horn and knows it's must be Spearman stuc on the side street. The mechanic starts his truck. Desperate not to lose him (and his money), Richie hurries over to a taxi stopped at a light, flashes his badge.
Get out.
What?
Get the fuck out of the car!

The driver realizes the man outside his taxi is crazy and tries to get his window rolled up. Reaching in, Richie ge his arm stuck, pulls at the lock, yanks the door open, dr the driver out, breaking the cabbie's arm, and jumps in. He swings the cab into opposing lanes to get around traff screeches around the corner, glimpses the truck far up ah - guns the engine, flies through a red light, glances at mirror at the cars that just missed him almost colliding The truck turns up ahead, and Richie barrels through anot red light, turns the corner and keeps the truck, a couple car-lengths ahead - in sight.
Richie curbs the cab as the guy goes into a dingy pizza parlor. Richie climbs out, crosses the street. Coming pas the place, he tries to look inside without breaking strid

From around a corner, striding toward him, come four men looking like Gestapo thugs in leather coats, manicured ha the Princes of the City. Richie detours into an alley as they enter the restaurant. Richie peers in at the restaurant kitchen through a grimy basement window. Watches Trupo and his SIU detectives bur in, guns drawn. They rough everybody up, get some down on the floor. One detective gathers the money and stuffs it a bag. Another gathers the dope. The mechanic tries to protest and Trupo slaps him down with his pistol. Richie keeps watching as the NY cops arrest no one - but take the dope and the money (Richie's money) - and stride out as abruptly as they appeared, like bandits. As they come past Richie -
That's my money.
The fuck are you. What money?
Richie shows them his Bureau of Narcotics ID.
The bills are sequenced and registered with the Essex County Prosecutors Office. All begin with CF3500. Take a look.
One of them checks some of the bills and sees he's right.
Goddamn it, I thought we had a score. I thought I had a fucking Chris-Craft sitting in my driveway.
Honest mistake. Just give it back to me.
This time.
Three of the four cops laugh. It's an affable gang of thieves. The one who doesn't laugh hangs back as the othe start off. He examines Richie's New Jersey ID.
When's the last time I was in Jersey? Let me think. Never. What're you doing coming over here without letting anybody know? You don't know you can get hurt doing that?
(Trupo smiles; Richie smiles) You got your money. Now, never, ever, come into the city again unannounced. You come in to see a fuckin Broadway show you call ahead first to see if it's okay with me.
Trupo pats him on the back and leaves with the others.
What do we hate most? Isn't it the transgressions of others we fear we're capable of ourselves?
It's very late.    Richie and Toback are alone.      Even
Richie - cops are like -

Yeah, I know, like everyone else. Some of them will steal no matter what. There can be a camera on them they'll do it. Some'll never do it. The rest are capable of either, depending how their department leans ... Only theirs isn't leaning, it's fallen over. The patrol cars don't even stop in Harlem, just roll down the window so the dealers can throw the money in. I saw drops made on precinct steps.
What were you doing there?
It's where this dope is coming from. Blue Magic. Out of New York. What am I supposed to do, ignore it?
The cab driver's filed aggravated assault and grand theft charges -
He wouldn't stop. Motherfucker almost ran me over.
- which he may reconsider depending on the amount the State of New Jersey offers to settle -
I told him I was a cop.      I showed him my identification.
You stole his cab and broke his arm.
I was chasing your 20 thousand dollars.
I don't want to hear about you going into New York anymore.
Then my investigation's over.

You're not listening to me. I said: I don't want to hear about it ... You do whatever you have to do, go wherever you have to go to find out who's bringing this shit into the country ... Just don't tell me. (turns to leave) Get some sleep.
Richie - in robe and underwear - opens the door to find a woman in the hall holding a briefcase.
Mr. Roberts?    I'm here for our appointment.

He has no idea who the black woman is. An old girlfriend he's forgotten maybe. Behind him, Vida can see a stewarde buttoning up her uniform by a little travel case on wheel The apartment itself, she can also see, is a mess.
From Child Social Services?
Barbecue after their Sunday softball game. Richie and his O.C. friends - wise guys - still in their brown and orang Weequahie jerseys, drinking beer, cooking hamburgers.
When you asked me to be your son's godfather, I took it very seriously.
I know. Richie and Tony Zaca relax in the den-like pool house.
I said yes, I'd take on this responsibility, take care of your son, God forbid something happened to you -
Tony, the things she's telling Child Social Services make me look very bad: Out all night. Lowlife informants hanging around.   Women -
Old friends like me. Richie feels horrible doing this.    Silence.   Then:
It's all right. I understand. They ask me, I'll tell them what you want me to tell them. I'll lie for you.
Thank you. Tony nods, You're welcome.    Can tell there's something on Richie's mind.
What.
You don't have to talk about it, you don't want. What do you hear about Blue Magic? Anything?
A lot of sorrow and misery from guys being put out of business. That's all.
Nothing about who's bringing it in?
Guys down south is all I heard.
Down south, Florida?   Cubans?   What.
I don't know. All I can tell you is whoever it is, they're upsetting the natural order of things.
Among the framed family photos around them, is a picture of Tony's uncle, Albert Tosca.
A Napoleonic statue of the same man on horseback in a fountain outside a castle-like mansion. Next to it "ride" three others on marble horses - a woman and two children.
Pull -

A clay pigeon sails out across the manicured garden. A shotgun blast shatters it. The man with the gun - Albert Tosca - hands another to Frank. As Frank sets to shoot, A can seen behind them, with Tosca's wife in the opulent house, looking uncomfortable.
The whole place was imported brick by brick from Gloucestershire.
It's very nice.
Mrs. Tosca nods. Ana nods. A strained silence thicker tha the tapestries settles over them until -
Pull -
The shotgun booms -
As servants stand by, Tosca and his wife and their only guests - Frank and Ana - finished with lunch, get up from the table in the formal Formal dining room.
As Mrs. Tosca leads Ana off to give her a tour of the hou the men head off the other way.
She's a lovely girl.    You should marry her.
Too many things to look after right now to think about that.
Frank. That's a mistake. If I may say. Don't take her for granted, girl like that.
They enter a rich, wood-paneled study lined with books.
You interested in history, Frank? The events that have brought us to where we are today? You know who was? Bumpy.
Bumpy was interested in a lot of things.
I always wonder if people know when history's being made. And what they're doing at the time. This, for instance, could be a historic moment, and you're sipping a glass of ice water.
Droplets snake down Frank's glass. He senses Tosca has finally gotten around to why he was invited here.

Bumpy and I did a lot of business together, as you know. Whatever he needed, he'd come to me and I'd do my best to provide it. He came to me, I didn't go to him, is the point I'm trying to make. You know why?
He didn't have what you needed. You had what he needed. We've always had to come to you.
Yes.   Until now.
Tosca studies Frank, who is a study in inscrutability.
Monopolies are illegal in this country, Frank, because no one can compete with a monopoly. If they let the dairy farmers do that, half of them would go out of business tomorrow.
I'm just trying to make a living.

Which is your right. Because this is America. But not at the unreasonable expense of others. That's un-American. (he studies Frank) You know the price you pay for a gallon of milk doesn't represent its true cost of production. It's controlled. Set.
I set a price I think is fair.
It's very unfair, in fact. Your customers are happy, but what about your fellow dairy farmers? You're not thinking of them.
(very calmly) I'm thinking of them as much as they ever thought of me.
All right. I can see you're getting excited. Don't get excited. That's not why I invited you to my home. To get excited.
Frank doesn't look excited at all. He's the picture of calm. Tosca smiles benignly and gets up.
Here, I got something for you.
Tosca opens a humidor, takes out a couple of Cuban cigars
Now what if - I'm just thinking out loud - you sold some of your inventory wholesale and I helped with the distribution.
I don't need it. I already got everything from 110th Street to Yankee Stadium, river to river.

Which is a little mom and pop store compared to what I'm talking about. I could make you bigger than K-Mart. L.A., Chicago, Detroit, Vegas. I'm speaking nationwide. And I'd guarantee you peace of mind. You know what I mean by that.
Frank does. It's a backhanded threat.        Tosca clips cigars with a gold guillotine

Frank. You can see I'm a Renaissance man. Unfortunately not all my people are as enlightened. Ask them, What is civil rights, they don't know. They're not as open to change from the way things are done and who's doing it. But I can talk to them so there won't be any misunderstanding. That's what I mean by peace of mind.
Frank knows, in truth, he's not being given any choice in this matter. Still, maybe it's not so bad.
You pay what a kilo now, 75, 80? I'd consider 50. And I can get you as much as you want.
Tosca slips on his best poker face. Fifty thousand a kilo would be an extraordinary coup for him.
You see, I was right. This is a historic moment. You're going to be bigger than Bumpy himself.
He hands Frank one of the cigars, expertly prepared.
Can't smoke it here, unfortunately. Grace doesn't like it. Take it with you.
Doc waits by the car as Frank and Ana walk toward him. The Toscas wave goodbye from the front step of the mansio Frank slips the cigar into his top pocket as they climb i
Why would you trust these people, the way they look at you?
They look at me like it's Christmas and I'm Santa Claus.
They looked at us like we're the help.
(kisses her cheek)
No.   They're working for me now.

A TV: Muhammad Ali, the black man's black man, and Joe Frazier, the white man's black man, at their 1971 Madison Square Garden press conference where Ali says as much. Most of the guys watching it. Richie isn't. He comes over to Table of Organization. Tacks his Bar Association notice to it. Regards the photographs, like tentacles of octopus yet to have a head. Only the lowest section is made up of blacks (including Charlie Williams and Jackie Fox, but not Frank Lucas). Th rest of the faces are white and stop about midway up. They've hit a wall they can't get past.

Another TV here: Howard Cosell, ringside at the Garden as the first early fans arrive, pointing out that the fight, because of the political stand Ali's taken, is less about boxers than war versus anti-war. Frank chooses a linen jacket from his extensive color- coordinated racks of Phil Cromfeld suits as Ana, in her lingerie, puts on make-up at a vanity. He comes up behind her and sets down a small jewelry box.
The TV in the background as Richie puts a camera with a l lens in a sports bag and reaches for his coat -
Ana's reflection in the vanity mirror as Frank slips the engagement ring on her finger. She wipes at a tear, then gets up and hugs him.
Yes.
She kisses him.     Admires the ring.     And -
I bought you something, too.

She crosses past the TV, takes a garment bag down from he side of the closet, lays it on the bed next to Frank's su jacket. She takes hold of the zipper but doesn't immediately pull it, hoping perhaps to create some dramat tension.
What is it?
She unzips the bag like she's unveiling great art. But instead of seeing what's inside, we're allowed only Frank reaction: his smile of anticipation slowly changing to chagrin.

Richie observes celebrities and gangsters arriving in limousines - Sammy Davis Jr. and his wife, Joe Louis and his, Tosca and some of his guys - then enters the arena a another limo pulls up. Ana climbs out.
Come on. You look great. (no one else emerges) You want to miss the fight? Come on.
Finally, a patent leather shoe pokes out, sets down on th curb. Then its mate beside it. The shoes step away from the limo and -
Pre-fight. Richie, blended in with the a group of press photographers, regards the organized crime figures ringsi He takes a few pictures with the long lens camera as -

The owner of the gleaming patent leather shoes is shown t his second row ringside seat just behind the sports write and we move up the full-length chinchilla coat to Frank's uneasy expression - Richie's camera roams the faces of the prime ticket holde ringside: organized crime figures, celebrities, politicia women with plunging necklines and platinum hair -
Excuse me -
Richie can't believe it's Joe Louis brushing past him -
Mr. Louis -
Joe looks back as Richie approaches him -
I'm sorry, but I just have to tell you, sir, you were a hero to me growing up. I still push elevator buttons eight times for the rounds you beat Billy Conn in. For luck.

Louis acknowledges Richie only slightly more than not at all. Turns away to join his friends. Richie watches after him, stung by Louis's disregard. He snaps a picture of an Italian wise guy he doesn't recognize ... sifts the camera's view past Frank in the chinchilla coat ... then returns to him, watches as Tosca and his guys sit down behind Frank. Richie can't hear - but can see - their good-natured exchange -
Hey, Frank, you keep that hat on, I'm gonna miss the fight -

The odd thing to Richie is, Chinchilla's seat is better than all the Italians'. Detective Trupo notices this, too Richie focuses on the Chincilla's date, a stunning girl, beauty queen, then shifts back to her boyfriend who's now shaking the proffered hands of other Italians, then Don King. Joe Louis himself - who barely acknowledged Richie' existence - comes over and playfully exchanges "punches" with the man in the chinchilla coat. A sudden roar from the crowd as the lights go out except for the spot on the ring. Ali and Frazier are coming down the steps through the crush of fans and reporters, preced by soldiers carrying flags -

Richie tries to find the guy in the chinchilla coat, but he's hidden by a flag. Then he glimpses him again just as Ali shakes his hand before climbing into the ring - Flashbulbs pop throughout the arena as Robert Goulet begins the National Anthem. Ali pointedly doesn't sing along. Richie frames the shadowy figure in the chinchilla coat, focuses as sharp as he can in the bad light, and snaps the shutter -

Richie tacks the photograph of the man in the chinchilla coat to his Table of Organization - low and off to the si by other pieces of the puzzle that don't fit, other new faces with no names. Spearman holds a scrap of paper -
That's is the plate number on the limo. Check with the company, who rented it.
He's a supplier at most. Or just a pimp. We'd've heard of him otherwise.
No, he's bigger than that. His seats were phenomenal; better than Al Tosca's. Joe Louis and Ali shook his fuckin hand.
They look from Tosca's high position on the board to Fran low one, and a wedding march played in traditional fashio on organ begins and carries over:
From above, a sea of ladies' hats, all coral and pink. Below, Frank stands at the altar, waiting for his bride.
His name is Frank Lucas ...

Toback sifts through documents Richie has gathered: limousine company records, Frank's thin arrest record, mu shots of him years younger, the photograph from the fight and some more from subsequent surveillances.
Originally from Greensboro, North Carolina. Couple of arrests years ago. Gambling, robbery, unlicensed firearm.
For fifteen years he was Bumpy Johnson's collector, bodyguard and driver. He was with him when he died.
Ana's family and friends on one side of the aisle, the extended Lucas family - on the other. Frank's mother look at her eldest son at the altar with pride.
Five brothers, he's the oldest, lots of cousins, all living here now, spread out around the boroughs and Jersey. The brothers are -
A Lucas brother hands some dry cleaning to Spearman -
Eugene Lucas in Brooklyn -
Another Lucas brother examines a lamp with a frayed cord brought in by Jones.
Earl Lucas in Newark -
Another brother at the register, hands Abruzzo a receipt
Lester Lucas in Queens -
Another brother is photographed by Spearman from a parked car as he changes tires on a car up on a hoist.
Turner Lucas, the Bronx -
Richie kicks a dent into the fender of his old car.
As an appraiser writes up an estimate, Richie observes Teddy, attending to paperwork inside.
And Teddy Lucas, in Bergen County.
A photograph of Teddy goes up on the T.O. next to Frank a the other brothers and some cousins -
Except for the chinchilla coat, which no one can explain, Frank's life seems orderly and legitimate.
Best Man Teddy standing next to Frank at the altar as the bride is escorted down the aisle by her father. Tight on Frank in a beautiful tuxedo -
A light goes on in a penthouse window. Down below, by his parked car, Richie shivers in the early morning cold.
He gets up early. Five a.m.
Has breakfast at a Midtown place, usually alone.
Richie tosses a glance inside a restaurant as he passes t window to where Frank sits eating at a table, Doc nearby.
Then goes to work. Meeting with his accountant, or lawyer, dropping in on one of the several office buildings he owns.
Nights, he usually stays home. When he does go out, it's to a club or dinner - with his new wife - friends, celebrities, sports figures - never O.C. guys.
Richie sits in his car across from Small's where bouncers keep out people like him. Frank, Ana, Wilt Chamberlain an his wife emerge from the restaurant together.
Sundays he takes his mother to church. Then drives out to change the flowers on Bumpy's grave. Every Sunday, no matter what.

Frank's mother tearfully watches her son slip a ring onto Ana's finger next to the fat engagement diamond - before Ana, in turn, puts a gold band on Frank's. The minister pronounces them husband and wife, the veil is lifted, and they kiss to great applause -
As a photographer takes the official photograph of the wedding party on the steps of the church -

Lou Toback looks from a surveillance photo of the wedding party in his hands, to Richie's Table of Organization: Th Lucas brothers and cousins - in the streets of New York a New Jersey, arranged in some imagined hierarchy.
Not your typical day in the life of a dope man, Richie.
Neither was Bumpy Johnson's and he owned Harlem.
You think Frank Lucas took over for Bumpy Johnson? His driver? That's a little far-fetched.
Is it?   Everything he does, he does like Bumpy.
Bumpy never wore a chinchilla coat in his life.
We haven't seen that again. That apparently has been retired to the closet.
Frank and Charlie look on as Ana throws the bouquet.
She's the most beautiful bride I ever saw, Frank.
I wish Bumpy could've met her.     I wish she could've met him.
Looking at the Lucas Table of Organization -
What do you got on him you can use in court? Because this isn't it. You try this without informants and powder, no one's going to jail.
Won't get any informants. Not inside. It's like a Sicilian family. Like he's structured his own family the same way to protect himself.
Exactly like one, like a scene from The Godfather as Fran dances with Ana before the reception guests.
Being with Bumpy long as he was, he would have been around Italians a lot. Enough to learn that much.

Rice rains down on the bride and groom as they climb into the back of the Towncar. Doc comes around to the driver's side, gets in and slowly pushes through the crush of gues waving and throwing kisses.
But it's not even Frank Lucas I want. I want to know who he's working for: Which Italians are bringing the heroin in.

Flanked front and rear by Frank's security, the marriage car moves along a rain-slick street. The newlyweds cuddle in back. Another car pulls up alongside - Trupo's Shelby and Doc's right hand instinctively comes off the steering wheel to settle on his holstered gun. Trupo smiles and shakes his head, no.
The Lincoln and security cars and Trupo's Shelby parked.
(to Ana)
Stay in the car As Frank and Doc climb out, Frank motions to his other security men to remain calm, he'll handle this.
Hello, Frank. If Frank is surprised Trupo knows his name, he doesn't sh it, or anything else except an air of professional courte
Detective. Trupo looks in at Ana in the back seat, smiles at her. Sh turns her head away and closes the door. Trupo leads Fran away for a private conversation -
You sure you done the right thing? She's a beautiful girl - there's no question - but she's got an attitude on (her) -
Listen   to me. Before you say another word -   about her - or me - remember that you're   saying it on the most important fuckin   day of my life.
Man walks around in a fifty thousand dollar chinchilla coat and he never even bought me a cup of coffee? Something wrong there.
I don't know what you're talking about.
You pay your bills, Frank?
You want to keep talking, talk to my lawyer, here's his card. You call him, because we're done here -
Do you pay your bills, I asked you.
If you're not getting your share, it's not my fault, go ask the chief of police.
What's my share? You don't even know me. Maybe I'm special.
No, you're all the fuckin same.

(shows his shield) What does that say? (Frank ignores him) Special - Investigations - Unit. See that word there? "Special." (he takes out a restaurant business card) Ten grand, first of each month, delivered here.
Frank ignores the card, stares at Trupo like he's a fool.
Detective ... There are some things you don't do. This is one of them. Not on a man's wedding day.
Frank's resolve throws Trupo off his rhythm.           He
Have a nice honeymoon.

Frank doesn't carry Ana across the threshold. He strides leaving her at the front door, throws a match in the gas fireplace, comes back from the bedroom a moment later wit the $50,000 chinchilla coat and throws it on the flames.
A march on Washington, protesting the war (archive).
The report continues on a TV here as Teddy's driver, Jimm Racine, yells at his girlfriend -
Where is it?
Fuck you, I'm not telling you.
She comes past the TV and into the kitchen past a table covered with dope paraphernalia.
Where is my fuckin dope? You and your girlfriends take it again? I'll fuckin kill you.
She yanks open a drawer, grabs a knife and slashes it at him. He grabs a gun and she runs for the stairs -
He chases her into the street, yelling, raises the gun an fires, and she goes down, clutching at her butt, moaning
Moaning here, too.   Richie's lawyer-ex-girlfriend, in be with him.
Richie, yes, fuck me like a cop, not a lawyer - (the phone rings)
Oh, God, Richie, no - don't answer it - (he reaches to pick it up)
No, no, no -
Yeah -
Richie. Newark just picked up one of the celebrities on our Wall of Fame: Teddy's driver. For attempted murder.

Richie's had Jimmy Racine brought over. Sits with him as the Three Amigos watch from the shadows. Just coming off his high, and the attempted murder, Jimmy looks disorient as he sits in cuffs in the dungeon-like basement.

Because it's an attempted homicide, that's Grand Jury. Now, that Grand Jury could come in very favorably. Might turn out to be Attempted Manslaughter. Self Defense even. She had a knife. Depends on how I want to deal with you. You see where this is going. Jimmy looks around at the basement dungeon with concern.
The fuck is this place?

Let's say you beat it somehow. What do you think Cousin Frank'll think of that? He knows you had to sit here listening to something like this. And then you beat an attempted murder? Is he stupid? He'll assume you talked. Jimmy can easily imagine that scenario and it frightens h
You fucked up, Jimmy. But nobody knows. Frank doesn't know. Yet. Do you want him to read about it in the paper? Or do you want to walk out of here - no bail, no trial - just walk out, now.
Jimmy has thought about it all night and walks out of the building into the chilly morning air.
Jimmy?   Look at me -
Jimmy looks over his shoulder as if Richie just called to him from it, which he didn't. There's no one in sight -

Any time I want to change my mind? I don't like the quality of your work? I can find a witness saw you shoot your girlfriend. It just took me a while. I even know what he'll look like. He'll look just like you.
Teddy's car comes around a corner and down the street.
Jimmy Racine, wired, looks in the rear view mirror at Ted in the back seat, and, behind him, Richie's car following
Richie keeps Teddy's car in view ahead. Glances in his mirror at the cars following him. His detectives.

The detectives' cars parked behind a warehouse. Richie peers into binoculars at: Teddy's car parked by Frank's outside another warehouse loading dock. Frank gets out, discusses something with his brother, comes past Jimmy to some men in bloody white coats. He talks to them, returns to his car, takes a valise from the trunk. He snaps it open revealing stacks of cash, han it over and walks to a semi-truck, glancing once in Richi direction. Though he can't see anyone there he gives a wa to them - or is it to the truck driver to pull out -
Like Bumpy used to do every Thanksgiving, Frank and his brothers, from the back of the truck, hand out hundreds o freshly-butchered turkeys to the poor.
Frank, in an apron, carries in a huge cooked turkey as th extended Lucas family gathers around the table. It's like Norman Rockwell painting -
Another Thanksgiving picture: addicts shooting up and nodding out in alleys and dingy rooms. Tight on needles, veins, spoons, filth -
Richie alone at his kitchen table with a sandwich and a beer. The Macy's parade plays silently on his TV.

A doorbell summons Trupo. He comes through his entry. Opens the front door. Finds no one there - except a large live turkey on the doorstep. He stares at it nonplussed, then looks up to a sound - a whoosh - as flames engulf th interior and spit out the windows of his Shelby Mustang .
The big knife in Frank's hand slices into the turkey and lifts meat onto a plate that's passed from hand to hand, family engaged in several conversations at once, laughing
Bathroom. Jimmy Racine, shirt off, wired, changes the batteries of the little tape recorder.
Jimmy comes out, tries to take a chair not too far from Frank who's watching his nephew toss pop-up flies for the younger kids to catch.
Stevie. Come over here. (the nephew comes over)
I heard you didn't show up.
You're     too busy to meet with Billy Martin?   After I set it up?
Stevie shifts around, not wanting to make Frank mad ...
I don't want to play pro ball, I decided.
What're you   talking about? This is your dream since   you were their age - (the   younger kids) Maybe I can   set it up again.
Stevie just stands there, uncomfortable.         Finally
It's not what I want. I want to do what you do, Uncle Frank. I want to be you.
Frank stares at him unhappily.       Teddy comes over but barely notices.
We got a problem.
Jimmy Racine behind the wheel.       Frank and Teddy in b speaking quietly.
He's been cutting it so much it's down to two, three percent pure.
You tested it. You're sure.
Teddy nods. Frank notices Jimmy looking at them in the re view mirror.
The fuck you looking at?
The car pulls up in front of a building in the clothing district. Jimmy stays while Teddy and Frank go inside.

Jackie's club looks like a set from a blaxploitation film Frank and Teddy, led by a bodyguard, come past some turke carcasses and other remnants of Thanksgiving to where Jac and a couple friends cavort with some naked girls.
Frank.   Welcome.
We need to talk.

Great.   Girls, get out. The girls gather their things and leave. Frank wipes at a modern leather chair with his handkerchief, throws it awa sits. Jackie lays out a couple lines, offers Frank a roll up hundred dollar straw. Frank shakes his head, no thanks
You talked to Charlie. You want to hear more about my Black Coalition. Let me explain it to you - But first, let me suck up a line of coke -
That's not why I'm here. (Jackie glances up from the powder. No?)
Everybody's happy, Jackie. Charlie, Baz, the cops, the Italians, everybody. Everybody except you.
I'm happy.
Then I don't understand. Why do you have to take something that's perfectly good the way it is, and wreck it? Jackie doesn't seem to understand.

Brand names mean something, Jackie. Consumers rely on them to know what they're getting. They know the company isn't going to try to fool them with an inferior product. They buy a Ford, they know they're gonna get a Ford.

Not a fuckin Datsun. (his look says, right?) Blue Magic is a brand name; as much a brand name as Pepsi. I own it. I stand behind it. I guarantee it and people know that even if they don't know me any more than they know the chairman of General Foods.
What the fuck are you talking about, Frank?
What you're doing, as far as I'm concerned, when you chop my dope down to five percent, is trademark infringement.
That.   That's what this is about.      Jackie nods, but
With all due respect, Frank, if I buy something, I can do whatever I want with it.
That's not true. That's where you're wrong.
If I buy a car, I can paint it, God damn it.
Jackie, you don't need to. You don't need to make more money than you can with Blue the way it is. No one does. At a certain point it's just greed.
What do you want, Frank?    You want me to call it something else?
I have to insist. You call it Blue Magic, that's misrepresentation.
Fine. I'll call it Red Magic, even though it doesn't sound as good.
That's all I'm saying.   Wrap it in red cellophane and -
Pink Magic.   Black Magic -
Whack it down to nothing, tie a bow around it and call it Blue Dogshit if you want, just don't let me catch you doing this again.
Jackie regards Frank for a long moment ...
Catch me? Insist? Infringement? I don't like these words as much as please - thank you - sorry to bother you, Jackie. These are better words to use you come into my place without an invitation.
Jackie waits to hear a kinder word but Frank doesn't offe one. Jackie nods, Fine, okay, but it's more like a warnin
Frank pulls a girl off Teddy's lap and points him toward the door. Jackie watches them leave.
They emerge from the building to where Jimmy waits.
Give me the keys; take a cab home.
Frank and Teddy driving in silence.        Eventually -
You don't go over there any more.
Teddy doesn't like it, but nods. Suddenly his face is illuminated by light reflecting in the rear view mirror, unmarked police car behind them, flashing its brights.
It's all right, pull over, what are they going to do? Give us a ticket?
But Teddy isn't as calm as he begins to pull over.
As Trupo and his partner climb out of their car and appro Teddy's -
Frank?   Some of it's in the trunk. Frank regards him with utter disbelief. Teddy shies as if he expects to get hit. The SIU detectives arrive.
Hello, Frank.
Detective. How's it going?        You have a nice Thanksgiving?
I did not, as a matter of fact.       Get out of the car. The Lucases climb out.
Where's the Shelby?
The Shelby's gone, Frank. Trupo reaches in the driver's side window, takes the keys from the ignition and comes around to the trunk. Frank an Teddy exchange a glance as it opens. Silence. Then -
Want to come over here a minute, Frank? Six kilos of heroin are illuminated by the trunk light. Frank and Trupo regard it in silence. Then -
Now what are we gonna do about this?
We're gonna shut the trunk and say good night, forget you pulled us over.
I got a better idea. Trupo reaches into the trunk, picks up two of the heroin bricks, tucks them under his arm and looks at Frank -
Or would you rather I took it all and threw you and your brother in the fuckin river?
I don't know, would you rather it's your fuckin house blows up next time?
They hold each others' stare for a long moment.
I loved that car.
I know.
Trupo closes the trunk and walks away with his cut of the heroin, calling to his partner -
Let's go.
As the SIU cops walk to their car, the perspective shifts through binoculars: Richie watching.
From outside the driver's side, Teddy's head, inside the car, suddenly smashes against the window, cracking it. Hi groan is interrupted by Frank's muffled voice -
Don't you ever put me in a car with dope in it.
Richie comes in, opens the fridge and stares in, his mind elsewhere. A ringing phone pulls him out of it.
Yeah.   Tony.    How's it going?

Tony's wife and daughters can be seen in the suburban backyard. Here in the kitchen Tony and Richie watch kerne of popcorn bounce off the inside walls of the first Amana microwave oven. It's noisier than modern ones.
