The fuck is a `micro' wave?
It's a scientific force like atomic energy. It rearranges the molecules.
Of what.
Of anything. Of popcorn. You don't want to put your head in there.
Tony rakes out the plain, `pre-microwaveable' popcorn, using his hand. Gives some to Richie. Half of it's burnt.
I can get you one of these. Just like this, brand new. I'll have it delivered.
No, thanks.   I don't want one.
Tony hands Richie some snapshots: The Zaca family on the slopes of a resort, and in and outside a beautiful snow- dotted cabin.
This is nice, where's this?
Aspen.   Just got back.    Had a great time.
I'd like to ski Aspen some day.
Know who we met? Burt Reynolds. I'm not kidding. Lot of people from Hollywood go up there now, buying up everything.
This is your place?
Are you kidding? You know what it's worth? Ski-in-ski-out, five bedrooms, sauna, everything. We were guests. (pause) No ... No, that's your place.
Everything seems to stop. Richie becomes aware of the sounds around them, the girls splashing around outside ..
Isn't there something we can do - about leaving the big guy alone? You know who I mean.
What Richie knows is that no matter what he does or says this point he's got a problem.
If I don't report what you just said to me, you know I could be in a lot of trouble. If I do, then it's you.
I'm hoping you won't do that.
Richie considers the room itself, measuring the odds of microphones and a recorder being in it somewhere.
I'm not taping it. How do you know? Because we're friends and I'm telling you. This is a real offer.
From who, your uncle? (Tony doesn't say)                                  Why would you do this? Why would you risk our friendship?
Because I care what happens to you.
You shouldn't have done it.
I had to. I had no choice. Neither do you. Leave Frank Lucas alone.
He's not important enough for you to do this.
Yes, he is.
Richie stares at Tony, then puts the pictures in his hand
Tell Marie I'm sorry I had to leave. You can tell her why.

Alone in the empty building, he stares at the T.O.: The higher echelon Italians like Tosca; lower echelon Harlem guys like Charlie Williams and Frank Lucas. He gets up then, untacks Frank's photograph from its lowl position and moves it to a place no black has ever occupi to the top of the pyramid - above the mafia.
Toback regards Frank's picture at top of the Lucas T.O.
INS, FBI, IRS - I can't get anything out of them. Nothing on his travel, his bank accounts, property holdings - nothing.
That's because they all think you're on the take and you think they are.

They don't want this to stop. It employs too many people. Cops, lawyers, judges, probation officers, prison guards. The day dope stops coming into this country, a hundred thousand people lose their jobs.
Toback isn't as sure the corruption of the official world that complete.
Richie.   Excuse me.
Spearman gestures to a couple of men in suits who want to talk to him.
Richie and Tobacke regard the two stone-faced FBI agents
Who took it out? (nothing from the agents) If there's a contract on me, it would be nice to know who took it out.
We can't say without compromising our source. You understand.
No.    I don't. Not when it's my life.
If you want, we can assign someone to you.
Who?    FBI?   You're going to protect me?
Richie almost laughs at the thought, looks to Toback. fact, none of this is funny.

Walking toward his apartment down its dark street, bag of groceries in arm, Richie becomes aware someone is followi him. He slows to let the figure get closer, closer, then turns fast, drops the guy and puts a gun to his head.
Don't shoot!    For God's sake.
Richie keeps the gun pressed against the guy's forehead.
Talk.
Are you Richard Roberts?      I got a subpoena.
Richie and Laurie sit with their respective lawyers, wait for the judge to appear. He leans over -
Laurie. I'm sorry I couldn't give you the kind of life you wanted. I'm sorry it was never enough. But don't punish me for being honest. Don't take my son away.
She stares at him in disbelief.        Then responds in a voice than his -
What are you saying? That because you were "honest" and didn't take money like every other cop, I left you?
The bailiff looks over, but she doesn't care.

You don't take money for one reason: to buy being dishonest about everything else. And that's worse than taking money nobody gives a shit about - drug money, gambling money nobody's gonna miss. (more people look over) I'd rather you took it and been honest with me. Or don't take it, I don't care. But don't then go cheat on me. Don't cheat on your kid by never being around. Don't go out and get laid by your snitches and secretaries and strippers. I can tell just by looking, she's one of them.
His lawyer.    Which is true.    Everyone's watching them
You think you're going to heaven because your "honest." You're not. You're going to the same hell as the crooked cops you can't stand.
All rise -
The same judge who sends a collection plate around sits before Richie and Laurie and their attorneys.

Your honor, a lot has been said here today about how unsavory Mr. Roberts' environment is for a child. How dangerous it is. I'm sorry, but this is our world. This is where we live and we tell him, Protect us. We give him that responsibility, and then say, Oh, but we don't trust you to raise a child. We don't think you're fit for that.
I'm not.
Silence. Sheila looks at him, but he's looking at Laurie, and speaks to her like they're alone in the room:
You're right. This is no place for him. Around me. Take him. The further away the better. For him.
The lights on the Rockefeller Christmas tree blink on to applause. A carol begins and continues over:
Seats covered with Christmas presents. Doc, driving, sees Trupo's car parked out front Frank's penthouse.
Frank -
Yeah, I see them.

Doc pulls to the curb outside Frank's building. As the doorman helps Doc with the big Christmas tree tied to the roof of the car, Frank crosses to Trupo's car with a coup of bottles of Crystal tied with holiday bows.
Here you go, boys.   Merry Christmas.
Charlie has come to visit. A Christmas carol plays as Fra strings the tree with some lights.

Paying cops is one thing, I understand that. I been paying them since I was ten - put more of their kids through college than the National Merit Award. This is different, this Special Investigations Unit. They think they are special.
They're fucking crooks.   No code of ethics.
Frank plugs the cord in and the tree lights up.
Someone's been following me. Besides cops. I see cars where they shouldn't be. Guys I don't know -
Me, too.
They regard each other.    The carol continues over:
Ana hangs tinsel on the tree as Frank gives the shepherd some dog toy presents he's bought. More to himself:
Bumpy hardly ever went out at a certain point. He stayed in - read - watched TV - played chess. I thought he chose to lead a quiet life. He didn't. He couldn't go out without something happening.
We can still go out.
Where? With who? Everyone I know is under surveillance. I can't even be with my family at Christmas anymore.

He gets up, pets the dog, and looks out the window at Christmas angels stretched across the street, at people o the sidewalk, wondering perhaps which of them are underco cops, at Trupo's car, still parked outside.
Why don't you just pay who you have to pay?
I do pay them, I pay them all. Cops, accountants, lawyers, who don't I pay? Everybody. I pay them a fortune, it doesn't matter. It doesn't satisfy them. The more you pay, the more they expect.
You can't start with them because they can't stop. It's like dope. They always want more.
Ana looks vulnerable. Frank almost feels bad that it's hi life and problems that have put them here. Eventually, to try to turn it around -
Put on something nice, we're going out.
Frank and Ana emerge from a service elevator, come down dark hall and out the back door to an alley to where Doc waits with the car in the falling snow.
Frank's car approaches Small's just as Jackie, with a Santa Claus hat on, climbs out of a sky blue Bentley with his entourage. Frank groans to Doc -
Keep going.
Around back?
Fuck that. I'm not going to sneak into my own club. Just drive.
Waiting for a take-out order under harsh fluorescent ligh
I'm going to wait in the car.
Go ahead, Frank.       I'll wait for it.
You can carry it all?      We ordered a lot.
Doc nods, go on, go with Ana. Frank hands him a couple twenties. Ana's already outside.
Don't forget the yellow sauce.
Ana's half a block ahead, waiting outside the locked car the time Frank arrives and realizes -
Doc's got the keys.   Let's go back.
The lights give me a headache, you go.
I'm not leaving you on the street.
Get the keys, Frank, it's cold.
He starts back through cascading snow.       Notices a ca slowly down the street -
The cook dumps sizzling vegetables into a take-out contai and puts it in a bag -
The car passes, continues to the end of the block, turns corner.
Doc hands over money, waits for his change -
Gimme some of that yellow sauce.

Frank sees the car again, coming around the corner, walks briskly back to where Ana waits. The car is almost upon them as he grabs her by the wrist and pulls her hard alon the sidewalk. The car guns its engine -

As Frank pushes in past the doors with Ana, the windows explode. They dive to the floor, bullets ripping through the place. Doc draws his two guns and fires back at the car, hitting it a couple times as it screeches off. He gathers Ana and Frank off the floor like a presidential bodyguard, hustle them out to the car. Frank's shoulder is bleeding.
You hit?
What the fuck was that?
They pile in and Doc screeches away from the curb.
Heavy security in the hallways: Frank's own men and some cops he's got on the payroll. Ana steps from the elevator and hurries past, early edition New York paper in hand.

The brothers watch as a private doctor attends Frank's wounds. He seems all right fine except for the fact that someone had the fucking nerve to take a shot at him - and Charlie he sees in the newspaper - gunned down, dead, lur Weegee-like photo of him on the front page.
Was it Jackie? (Frank doesn't say) I'll fuckin kill him whether it was or not, you tell me to. (nothing from Frank) What do you want us to do, Frank? We can't just sit here and -
Who didn't like Charlie?   Everybody liked Charlie ...
Who shot at us? (Frank can't tell her) It doesn't matter. We're leaving.
She pulls a drawer open. Takes out their passports. Begins packing. The brothers watch, not sure what to do, or say. To them -
Go home.   Go see your kids.
He obviously wants to talk to Ana alone. Pulls away from the doctor. They all leave. Ana keeps packing.
What are you doing?     Where've you been?
We're leaving from here.      Money's in the car.
What money?
Everything from your mother's house.
In your car?
Yes.
Where's the car?
Out front.
With ten million dollars in it?
I didn't count it.
Are you crazy? Take it back to Teaneck. What are you doing driving around without security? Doc'll take you back.
We're not going there, we're going to the airport. We're leaving the country.
To go where?    No, we're not.
Frank, Charlie's dead. They tried to kill us. What else has to happen - ?
He grabs her and holds her to calm her down.
Shhh.   Come on, now.   Shhh.
He holds her close, waits for her breathing to slow befor
Where are we going to go? Spain? China? Which fuckin place is it going to be?
We can go anywhere we want.     We can live anywhere.
We can run and hide is what you're saying.
He slowly shakes his head: that's something he'll never d
This is where I'm from. This is where my family is. My business. My mother. This is my place. This is my country. This is America.
The Statue of Liberty in morning light and mist rises fro the waters of the Hudson River.
Richie, at his desk, looks up to see Trupo walking throug the squad room, followed by Spearman.
Said he'll only talk to you.
Trupo's attitude has completely changed from the first ti they met. He talks to Richie now like a fellow conspirato

From what I hear, it was the Corsicans. The French Connection, Fernando Rey, the exporters Frank has put out of business. Now, I can take care of him in New York, but I don't want to have to worry every time he drives across the bridge to Jersey someone's gonna take another shot at him.
Richie gives nothing away even as it stuns him that Trupo would speak to him this blatantly.
We need to start working together. We need to step up our efforts. Next time their aim could be better. We need to keep this cash cow alive.

Jimmy Racine comes in - sees Trupo - and leaves - but not before Trupo has seen him. And now he sees the Lucas Tabl of Organization he didn't notice when he came in. Gets up and walks over to it now and takes a closer look. Sees Frank's picture at the top, like Enemy Number 1.
Jesus. What the fuck you doing here? You actually going to arrest Frank Lucas? What's the matter with you?
I'm crazy. Can't you tell that? I'm crazy enough to shoot someone and make it look like an accident next time he comes over the bridge without my permission. Get the fuck out of New Jersey.
They regard each other a moment before Trupo turns to lea

A large TV shows chaotic scenes in Saigon. The US is pulling out of Vietnam. Tosca has come to see how Frank i recovering, and finds him, agitated, too long in bed even though it's only been a day, changing into a nice shirt, putting on his shoes -
"I can guarantee you peace of mind," you said. Do I look like a man with peace of mind to you? They shot at my wife. Who does that?
Who was it, which one of your people? I'll take that gun away and shove it up their ass.
I don't know that it was any of them, Frank. Neither do you.
Then maybe I'll kill them all just to make a fuckin point.
Tosca seems more philosophical about it - like Bumpy migh have been - but it wasn't him who was shot at.

You want to know who it was? I can tell you. It was a junkie. Or a rival. Or some dumb ass kid trying to make a name for himself. Or someone you forgot to pay off. Or slighted without realizing it. Or someone you put out of business by being too successful. (pause) Success has a lot of enemies. Your success is who took a shot at you. How you gonna kill it? By being unsuccessful? You can be successful and have enemies, or unsuccessful and have friends. It's the choice we make.
A call has interrupted Nate's massage (and later activiti with a bevy of Thai girls. He wraps himself in a robe, takes the phone.
Hello?

Frank on a pay phone in a comfortable alcove with a stack of quarters. Other guests are gathered around a TV in the lounge that shows images of helicopters plucking diplomat off the roof of the American Embassy in Saigon.
I'm watching the news.     Where the hell's everyone going?
Home.    The war's over.
Just like that? We're going to leave the fuckin country to the communists?
We been here since 1961, Frank.
I haven't!
Frank and Nate and their "army" of black servicemen and T thugs wind through the jungle with pack mules.
The same farm and hut as before. Frank and the Chinese General sip tea. The four million dollars in cash Frank brought sits on the table.
Opium plants are hearty enough to outlive any war. They'll still be here long after the troops are gone. But what are you going to do for transportation when the last US plane goes home?
I'll figure something out.      You'll see me again.
The General seems fond of Frank, and not only because of the money on the table.
It's not in my best interest to say this, Frank ... but quitting while you're ahead is not the same as quitting.
That's what my wife thinks.
But you don't think she's right.
Frank doesn't say.
Mules are loaded up with burlap bags containing 3,000 kil of heroin.

The mule train approaches the jungle that surrounds the opium farm. Nate's Thai thugs, left behind in sniper positions in the trees, stand ready to open fire if they have to as Frank, Nate, the soldiers and mules pass below

They seem to have made it, winding back down through the jungle with the mules. Suddenly a barrage of gunfire erup from the trees - a couple of Nate's men are hit as the re dive for cover, shouting "Vietcong," and returning the fi Frank drops down from his mule, gets a pistol out and sho into the trees. Bullet-severed palm fronds rain down.
Give them half! Nate, pinned down by the mules, can't hear him over the noise.

Cut half of them loose!      The mules! Nate cuts the mule-train tether in the middle, slaps at t animals. As the freed mules disappear into a wall of tree the shooting subsides, then stops altogether. Smoke from all the gunfire rises like mist around the half dozen Tha and Americans lying dead on the ground.
Teddy makes out with a girl in the back seat of his car. The pay phone just outside on the corner rings, and he ge out, steps past Jimmy, answers it -
A Thai singer attempts Otis Redding on the little stage. Frank, at a table here, with a drink and a phone.
Newark.     Short Term Parking Lot 3.
When you need it? Today?
Tomorrow will be fine.
Jimmy loiters close enough to the open pay phone, to hear Teddy's side of the conversation.
Short Term Lot 3. This the Mustang were talking about ... Camero? ... What's the plate number? (writes on a napkin) Yeah, I got it ... I got it, Frank ... (sighs; reads from the napkin:) KA 760.
Jimmy's come over to share his news with the detectives. But Richie isn't pleased with it - or with Jimmy.
There's no Short Term Lot 3 at Newark. They're lettered, A, B, C, D -
I'm just telling you what I heard -
Then you heard wrong!
Jimmy shies back a step in case Abruzzo takes a swing.
Maybe he means the time?   3 o'clock?
And this isn't a Jersey plate. Or New York. Not with just two letters. It's three and three, not two and three -
It's what he said -
Then what the fuck is it -
The fuck should I know -
You're fuckin lying -
It's what he said.   I'm sure.
Yes!
Silence.   They all look at each other.       After a mom
None of you ever been in the service? It's an Air Force tail number.
The plane, with that tail number, descends through clouds
Richie's entire staff of detectives, along with Toback, t DA and several customs agents, stand on the tarmac, watch the military plane taxiing toward them -
Quiet sounds of suburban domesticity - chirping birds, a distant lawn mower -

The cabin door slides up, the passengers begin emerging: Military officers, embassy personnel and families. Richie detectives and Toback watch him with concern as the offic passengers, met by a bevy of assistants, file past -

The kitchen. Frank's mother shows Ana some old photograph of Frank as a boy as they sip coffee. There's a tap on th glass French door. The women look up and see Trupo just outside it, and other police moving past. He waves.
An Army captain approaches Richie's law enforcement group
Captain, I'm Richard Roberts, Director of the Essex County Narcotics Bureau.
Front door. Trupo sort of waves a search warrant at Julie as invites himself in. The NY cops follow, fan out. Trupo and his detectives head upstairs -

The plane has been brought into a hangar where it's being taken apart like a car stripped by thieves. Inside the cabin, seats are removed and inspected, carpeting pulled panels unscrewed, lavatories dismantled.

Downstairs - Ana and Frank's mother, guarded, can hear Trupo and his detectives, upstairs, ransacking a bedroom. Upstairs - the SIU detectives pull open drawers, throw clothes from the closets.   Trupo picks up an invitation a United Nations ball, tosses it down again. Finds a safe deposit box key in a sock drawer, puts it in his pocket.
The engines and landing gear are disassembled, the tires opened up and searched. A nozzle plunges into a toilet an pumps out the contents into barrels detectives fish throu with gloved hands -
Ana is taken upstairs, brought before the SIU detectives who wait for the NYPD cops to leave the room. The place has been torn apart.
Your husband's illustrious career is over. The Feds are going to come in and take it all. Everything. But not before I get my gratuity. Where's the money?
There was some on that dresser, but it's gone now so I guess you (took it) -
The money! The getaway money Frank and every other gangster keeps in his house!
If you leave now, there's a chance Frank might not kill you -
Trupo slaps her hard across the face -
Richie, off by himself, watches with a growing sense of panic as the mechanics, detectives and customs agents beg removing the metal skin from the plane. Coffins are being off-loaded.

Downstairs, Mama Lucas puts washcloth on Ana's swollen cheek. They can hear the search continuing upstairs: thin being ripped from the walls, the walls themselves splinte apart with sledgehammers, glass breaking. To Mama Lucas -
I'm sorry.

They've looked everywhere and found nothing. The plane, in fact, hardly resembles a plane anymore - no panel left that hasn't been removed, no cavity not probed - except - Richie's glance settles on the military caskets as they'r loaded onto a truck, armed soldiers standing guard -

head_text.subj: INT/EXT. MAMA LUCAS'S TEANECK, N.J. HOUSE

text: Frank's bedroom has been destroyed. Trupo, standing at a window glances out at the sound of a barking of a dog to Frank's German shepherd down in its kennel.
Richie gets up slowly and approaches the coffins as -
Trupo crosses the lawn toward the kennel and barking dog
Richie stands over the nearest coffin -
Open it.
The army captain regards the detective for a long moment.
The warrant permits me to search the plane and its cargo.
The captain doesn't comply. Richie moves to open the coff himself and every soldier's shouldered rifle immediately comes into firing position, aimed at him.
But you don't have my permission.
Richie stares at the weapons and the uniformed men holdin them, safeties off, fingers on the triggers; all they're waiting for is their commander's order to fire.
I don't need it.
Trupo regards the shepherd snarling at him from behind th kennel fence. Comes around back. Pushes at the frame. It moves a little, like it's levered -

With the rifles still pointed at him, Richie kneels down, pulls the latches of the coffins, half expecting to hear accompanying barrage of gunfire. He lifts the lid. Sees a long black body bag inside -
Trupo comes around to the front of the kennel again with gun out and aims it at the dog. As he fires -
Richie pulls at the zipper, parting the plastic body bag, revealing the remains of a young soldier -
That's enough.
The dead dog slides against the fencing as Trupo overturn the kennel to reveal Frank's stash of cash.
Richie and Toback sit before the Federal Attorneys and customs agents. The US Attorney hangs up a phone ... then

That was a military transport plane. If there was heroin on board then someone in the military would have to be involved. Which means that even as it fights a war that's claimed 50,000 Americans lives, the military is smuggling narcotics. Richie's in serious trouble and knows it.    As does Toba

That's how these events are being interpreted by General Easton in that call to me. That someone employed by the this office believes the United States Army is in the drug trafficking business - and is trying to prove it by desecrating the remains of young men who've given their lives in the defence of democracy.
There are drugs on that plane -

Shut the fuck up. Richie does, but can't conceal the contempt he feels for these men who've never spent a minute on the street but a as if know more than him, and who are, in the unfortunate organization of his world, his superiors.

Is it any wonder then, because of your actions, the entire federal narcotics program is now in jeopardy of being dismantled as completely and enthusiastic- ally as that fucking transport plane? That's what you've accomplished Mr. Roberts. Single-handedly.
I had good information the target of my investigation was bringing dope in on that plane.
And that target is?
Frank Lucas.
No one in the room, except Richie and Toback, has ever heard the name. The federal men regard one another blankl
Who?  Who's Frank Lucas? (no one seems to know) Who's he work for? Which family?
He's not Italian. He's black.
Now there's a longer, even deeper silence, before -
Is that supposed to be some kind of joke? You're this close to the end of your career in law enforcement, you're making jokes?

I believe Frank Lucas is above the mafia in the dope business. I believe he buys direct from the source in Southeast Asia, cuts out all the middlemen, and uses US military planes and personnel to bring pure No. 4 heroin into United States.
Richie is looking at faces that are still trying to make sense out of his ridiculous theory. Toback tries to come his defense -
Richie has a lot of experience -
Does he. And how many arrests has he made in his so-called investigation?
I was promised when I took this job, it was about real arrests.
Does that mean `none?'
I have cases against most of Frank's organization. Not him -
(more to the others) Frank's organization -
That's right.
No fucking nigger has accomplished what the American Mafia hasn't in a hundred years!
Yeah, you'd know, sitting here, having never been on the (street) -
Lou, get this fucking kike out of here -
Richie goes for him and lands several punches before Toba and the others can pull him off.
Richie and Toback walk briskly across the lobby -
He was out of line, Richie.
Richie isn't really listening. Strides past his detective on his way out of the building. To Spearman -
It's over.   You're shut down.
Toback watches as the detectives follow after Richie striding toward his car.
Frank comes out with an airline representative to find Do waiting for him. He can tell immediately something's wron
Frank slaps a cartridge into the butt of a pistol.
Ten million dollars means nothing to me.
Ana stares at the floor. It all just seems to get worse a worse. They had their chance to get out and missed it.
This - is his death warrant.
He lightly touches his wife's bruised face and walks out.
He comes down the stairs to where Doc waits.         As t for the door -
Frankie -
Frank glances to where his mother sits in the living room Nods to Doc to say, Get the car, I'll be out in a minute. Goes over to his mother.
Sit down.
He sits. She studies him in a way she hasn't since he was little. Eventually -

If you'd have been a preacher, your brothers would be preachers. If you'd been a soldier, they'd be soldiers. Do you know that? (he doesn't say) They all came here because of you. You called and they came running. They look up to you. They expect you to always know what's best. (pause) But even they know you don't shoot cops. Even I know that. Ana knows it. You seem to be the only one who doesn't.
Is that where I'm going?
I never asked you where all this came from because I didn't want to hear you lie to me. Don't lie to me. Don't do that, too.
She's not pleading, she's telling.       Silence.    Then
Do you really want to make things so bad for your family they'll leave you? Because they will. She will - (points upstairs) I know I will.

Frank has some trouble looking at her. But then gets up. Walks toward the front door to leave. Hesitates near it a long moment. Then turns and walks upstairs. Trupo will live, at least for now, because of her.

Down in the basement, the body bags are lifted from the wooden coffins. Set down on tables. The bags unzipped and the bodies removed. A rack of clean uniforms is brought in. The morticians begin dressing the corpses and applying make-up on the dr gray skin. New white military caskets are trundled in. Gold handles lifted. The bodies, clothed and painted now, are deposite on the silk linings. The lids of the coffins come down an cellophane bags containing folded flags are taped on top.
The white caskets are taken to a loading dock, put in a military truck. Papers are signed, copies exchanged. As the truck drives off -

Two black privates on janitorial duty come into the room where the original plain wooden coffins have been discard They remove the lids, then the finely-crafted false botto revealing in 4-inch cavities of each, tightly-packed bric of Double UO Globe heroin. As they take them out, a gospe choir begins and continues over:
A laundry truck idles. Stevie, the Lucas nephew who could have played for Yankees, jumps down, helps the two privat toss several laundry bags into the back of the truck.
A minister on the steps welcomes the congregation which includes Frank, his mother, and Ana -

The laundry truck comes past a guard gate, leaves the bas drives past a stand of trees. As it passes, Richie, parke by his detectives' cars, recognizes the young driver - wh wearing the same Yankee baseball cap in his T.O. photo. As Richie and his detectives climb into their cars, two Lucas cars fold in behind the laundry truck. The detectiv follow at a distance -

The sea of ladies' hats from above move in time with the gospel choir. As always, no matter what else is going on his complicated life, Frank sits with his mother and Ana their usual pew. The gospel music continues over:

Frank emerges from the church, kisses his mother and Ana put them in a car with a driver. He climbs into Doc's alone. His mother watches, wondering perhaps if he intend to go kill Trupo after all. As Doc's car leaves, so does another.
The laundry truck approaches a ramp leading to the George Washington Bridge. Richie, a couple of car lengths behind follows. The truck continues straight.
From overhead, the laundry truck, the gun car and the van and the detectives' cars following them all - converge fr different directions -

Red Top's van makes a turn. As Abruzzo's makes the same turn behind it, the infamous Stephen Crane Projects rise in his windshield. His foot comes off the gas. As the gun car passes, he sees Jones's car slow. Teddy's car approaches from anothe direction into the Projects, and Abruzzo sees Spearman pu over. Then the laundry truck turns in, and Richie's slows to a stop, like Abruzzo's, outside the grounds of the foreboding towers. The gospel music ends.
Doc waits in the car while Frank buys some flowers at a cemetery flower stand. The surveillance car cruises past.
Toback, in his bathrobe, glass of milk in one hand, phone the other ...
Where is it?
Somewhere in the South tower.
You know that it's there.     You're sure.
Positive.
Richie, on a pay phone across down the street from the Projects, looks up at the dark South tower.

Lou. We're ready to go in there knowing there's a good chance we won't all come out. That's what we're willing to do. All I'm asking you to do get me a warrant. Silence on the other end of the line ...
We don't have a lot of time to fuck around -
I'll call in the warrant. And some backup. Don't go in before either gets there.
This call disconnects.
The girls spread and tape plastic sheeting to tabletops, then begin changing for work, which means undressing.
Richie and his guys wait for the warrant by their cars.
How long we gonna wait for it?
Pharmaceutical scales balance to their counterweights as the five naked, masked women cut the heroin with quinine Frank's exacting standards. Red Top puts on some coffee.
Richie stares down the street, waiting for whatever it is they're waiting for. Spearman looks at his watch.
It'll be here.

A paper-cutter blade slices a sheet of blue cellophane. The girls at the tables, with the expertise of Cuban ciga makers, wrap pieces of the cellophane like tobacco leaves around precisely-measured 1/4-ounce drifts of Black Magic
Frank's car winds up the road of the cemetery. The surveillance car comes through the main gate and parks.
Several black and white and undercover cars approach, sirens off. Toback himself climbs out of one of the cars and hands Richie the search warrant.

The tall buildings cast long shadows of dread on every activity below, no matter how routine: A woman pushing a stroller, guys shooting hoops, a couple arguing, kids on bikes, old men resting on a graffiti-covered bench. The unmarked cars drive slowly through it all. The place teeters on the brink of violence you can feel as gangs mo under the shadow of the towers.

location: GROUND FLOOR, SOUTH TOWER, THE PROJECTS

text: Richie removes the cover plate of an elevator, cuts the wires, disengaging it, then leads the Amigos, followed by more detectives to a stairwell. The place is like Beirut. Debris-strewn, graffiti-covered.

Frank walks past graves to Bumpy's. Replaces some dried flowers with fresh ones. Looks around for something to si on. Sees some wooden folding chairs around a fresher grav nearby. Doc waits by the car in the distance.

Floor by floor, they work their way up the tower like commandos, the squalor and decay and hopelessness somehow intensifying the higher up they go. Reaching the 17th floor, they listen to a strange sound before easing the fire door open enough to see a kid on a Big Wheels pedalling straight at them. He passes and the sound fades.

Half the apartment doors are gone. TVs and radios echo, voices argue, infants wail. The detectives come around a corner and see at the end of it: a couple of guys with a sawed-off shotguns sitting outside a closed door. They step back. Consider one other. Spearman volunteers with a nod, continues on alone as the others wait. He wal up to the guys with the guns.
I got to talk to Teddy.
Get the fuck out of here.
What the fuck is that? I got business with Teddy and it's none of your fuckin business except to knock on the fuckin door and get him.

As the guy stands, pumping the shotgun, Spearman yanks it hard against his throat like a garrote, forcing him to th floor. The shotgun explodes, showering plaster and pellet Jones and Abruzzo are instantly all over the other guy as Richie swings the sledgehammer into the door -

The door splinters - the room already in chaos - Teddy, panicked, runs for the bedroom - the detectives crash in yelling at the girls to get down - a shot from somewhere inside wings Abruzzo - Jones and Spearman firing back - crawling across the floor like an infantrymen - Richie comes into the darkened bedroom leading with his pistol. But Teddy's gone. He sees a tapestry of a tiger o a wall. Pulls at it, finds a big hole knocked into anothe dark apartment, climbs through, sees an open door -

As Richie rushes out to the hallway he can hear footfalls echoing in the stairwell. He starts down, taking the stai five at a time, chases Teddy down two flights - Teddy yanks open a door, runs down a corridor, bangs into an apartment. Richie reaches the apartment just as Teddy goes out onto an exterior balcony - Richie continues along the interior corridor, running parallel to Teddy on the balcony, who trips over some deb and garbage, looking over his shoulder for Richie - Richie cuts through another apartment to head him off, bu the door to the balcony is nailed shut. So are the window Richie looks around, grabs a small portable television an just as Teddy runs past, hurls it through a window at him hitting him in the head. He falls hard, dazed. Richie hurries through the broken window. Teddy comes to and fights back, until Richie brea his femur with his bare hands. Teddy howls in excruciatin pain -
Police cars outside.    Eugene Lucas is cuffed and led aw
More police outside Lester's place.     They cuff him.
New Jersey troopers cuff Turner Lucas and lead him away.
Cuffed, Earl Lucas is put in the back of a patrol car.

Frank, on a wooden folding chair at Bumpy's grave, hears the gunning of engines and barking of cops. He turns to s Doc being handcuffed on the ground by the Towncar. Glance to a lone figure walking toward him over a rise. Richie. Richie arrives at the grave. Regards the monument to Ellsworth Johnson, and Frank sitting calmly regarding him Richie glances around the peaceful surroundings ...
What kind of trees are these? Frank looks at the trees, then at Richie, with equal serenity.
You think you got Frank Lucas.      You got nothing.
Richie cuts the tags off a new, inexpensive suit. Slips the jacket on, which seemed somehow to fit a little bette at the store. Cuts the tags off a tie.

Someone throwing up in a stall. The toilet flushes, the door opens and Richie steps up to a sink, regards his fac in the mirror. Under the fluorescent lights - maybe under any kind - his skin is a shade of death. He splashes wate on it and tries to gather himself.
At the prosecutors table, Richie steals glances at the battery of expensive attorneys over at the defense table.

The courtroom doors swing open and Richie sees Frank Luca in a tailored suit, escorted in without cuffs by an amiab looking federal marshal. As Frank moves through the gallery, Richie sees it's full the gangster's friends, many of them celebrities, who smi and greet and fawn as if the Pope has arrived. Richie has evidence tables covered with cash, weapons, stocks, bonds, property deeds, pictures of Frank's holdin heroin in blue cellophane. Frank has celebrities, community leaders, Joe Louis himse who will testify to Frank's benevolent character. The Cha hugs the heroin trafficker warmly in front of everyone an Richie wonders if he should just give up now. Richie sees it in slow motion: the hands reaching out to Frank, the pats on his back, lipsticked mouths of beautif women offering kisses and words of encouragement, his old mother giving him a hug. He watches Frank's head turn slowly, his eyes passing his phalanx of attorneys, the jury, finally settling on Richi in his cheap suit seated at the prosecutors table. Frank's eyes smile as they regard Richie, and seem to ask Can you see this - can you see what you're up against - c you see how insignificant you are? Reaching the end of the welcoming line finally, Frank brushes by Richie and disappears from view somewhere with the protective husk of his multi-million-dollar legal tea
Mr. Roberts -
Richie slowly lifts himself from his chair, steps forward turns to look at the jury that's studying him, finally fi his voice:
Thank you, your Honor.   Ladies and gentlemen -
Wire mesh separates Frank from his battalion of lawyers. He glances over them to Richie being led through the larg Visiting Room.
Here he is, let me talk to him alone.
The attorneys get up and leave. Richie takes their place. Frank regards him a moment, offering the same knowing smi from the courtroom. Richie offers nothing.
I just heard something. I said it couldn't be true. You didn't really turn in a million dollars you found in the trunk of a car, did you?
Richie doesn't say. Frank searches his face for some clue to where on earth he's from.
Want me to tell you what happened to it? It ended up in cops' pockets.
Maybe.
Maybe? No. It did. All you did was give it to them for nothing in return. Not nothing: You got their contempt.
Frank studies him.
Why'd you do that? What're you trying to prove, you're better than them? You're not better than them. You are them.
I don't have the time or interest to listen to (this) -

You did it because it was right. That's all. Why's that hard to say? The question is would you do it again? That was a long time ago. It'd be very easy to find out. Tell me you want to find out, tell me the address, and a car will be there, the trunk loaded.
Richie knows Frank isn't kidding ...
No, thanks.
Frank suddenly explodes -
Who the fuck are you to say no to that? You think that impresses me?
Guards look over, then glance away once it's clear the outburst is through. Richie remains serene. Eventually -

Let me ask you something. You think by putting me in jail, you're going to stop even one junkie from dying? Because you won't. If it isn't me, it'll be someone else. With me or without me, nothing's going to change.
Then that's the way it is.
You have any sort of case? Or just that idiot drives for my brother. Is he your case? Because if it's just him and the powder, it's not enough.
Then you got nothing to worry about.
But Frank is worried, most of all by this cop who doesn't take money sitting placidly in front of him.
My brothers won't talk to you. My cousins. None of my family. No one but that mother fucking driver.
I got more than that. I got a line of people wanting to testify that stretches out the door and around the block.
Bullshit.
Is it? Tony the Bug.     Benny Two-Socks. Carmine Camanetti.
Who the fuck are they? I don't know them and they don't know me.
They sell dope for the Mazzano crime family. Which you all but put out of business.
This is who you're going to put on the stand? Guys who don't know me? Who got nothing to do with me?
They have everything to do with you. And the only thing they hate more than you is what you represent.
I don't represent nothing.
You don't? Black businessman like you? Of course you do. But once you're gone, things can return to normal.
Look at me. You looking? Can you tell by looking it would mean nothing to me if tomorrow you turned up dead?
Get in line. That one stretches around the block, too.
Frank has never been so frustrated by anyone in his life. He wants to work something out with Richie obviously, but can't figure out how. Frank studies him.
What can we do?
You know what you have to do.
Frank does, but doesn't like it, and doesn't know if he c do it.
I could give you cops, but that's not who you want, is it. You want organized crime names.
I'll take them, too.   I want them all.
Frank isn't sure he heard right.
You'll take them, too? You'd go after cops? Are you serious? You'd do that? Lock up your own kind?
They're not. Not the ones in business with you. They're not my kind any more than the Italians are yours.
They regard one another in silence.      Richie can tell sees daylight.
What can you promise me?

I can promise you if you lie to me about one name, you'll never get out of prison. Lie about one dollar in one offshore account, you'll never get out. You can live rich in jail the rest of your life, or poor outside it, that's what I can promise.
Frank is silent for several moments.      Finally -

You know, I don't care if the feds take all my buildings, my stocks, my off-shore accounts. They can take it all, I don't care - use it to build battleships, paint bridges, whatever the fuck they want. Fight another war. But those other motherfuckers - the cops - put my money in their pockets. Millions.
I believe it.
Frank debates with himself the step he's about to take ..
I want to know everyone   you've met for the last twenty years.    Everyone you sold to. Every cop you ever    paid off. Every one who ever stole from   you. Every one you remember.
Oh, I remember them all.   That's not the problem.
What is?
The jail's aren't big enough.

location: COUNTY JAIL CELL / STREETS OF NEW YORK

text: Surveillance photographs of cops seen earlier taking envelopes of money on 116th Street and other drops go up on a new, elaborate Table of Organization - of cops.
Richie dismantles the Lucas Table of Organization here, taking down the photographs. As it collapses -

Frank puts up photographs of detectives - 347   QUICK CUTS of the same detectives, in handcuffs, le police stations past other cops watching with dread like maybe they're next - A surveillance photograph of the four Princes of the City striding down a sidewalk goes up on the cell wall - 348   FLASHCUT as three of the four SIU cops are led away from a golf course - 349   A surveillance photograph of Trupo in a black hand
You go up here. Your "special."
As Frank tapes the picture of Trupo at the top of the pyramid of corruption -

Trupo, coffee in hand, comes into his garage from his kitchen. Opens the garage door and sees two squad cars parked outside ... 351   A TV: A report on the indictments handed down by th Manhattan DA's office against 53 NYPD and SIU detectives

Frank gathers his few personal belongings and puts them i a box. Stands with the box and waits for the cell door to open. The Table of Organization and files are gone. Legend:   Frank Lucas was convicted of Conspiracy to Distribute Narcotics and sentenced to 70 years. He served 15 of them. Legend:   Federal authorities confiscated over 250 millio dollars from him in real estate, equities and cash in US and foreign banks.

Richie, too, is packing, putting personal items into boxe Legend:   The day after he convicted Frank Lucas and 30 o his Country Boy relatives, Richard Roberts borrowed $400 from his credit union to help pay for a 3-day vacation to the Bahamas. Richie, carrying the box, switches off the lights and clo the door behind him on his way out. Legend:   Six months later, he quit the Prosecutors Offic to become a defense attorney. His first client was Frank Lucas.

Frank steps out into sunlight, free but owning nothing bu the cardboard box in his arms. Looks out across the parki lot to see if anyone has come to pick him up. Sees Richie by his car, hand raised above his head like a flag.

The two of them stand outside Richie's car on the same corner Frank shot Tango. Frank looks up at the street sig that used to say 116th Street and 8th Avenue. Now they sa 116th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard.
Frederick Douglass Boulevard? What was wrong with just plain 8th Avenue? He considers the street itself. It too has changed. The corner groceries, as Bumpy prophesied, really are gone no
I used to sit here with Ana in my old car. She hated it. Now I don't even have a car. Or her.
Frank glances to where his favorite diner used to be, and across the street to where he shot Tango. It isn't a frui stand any more.
Just do what?
What?
The fuck is that? Just do what?
It's a Nike store with huge paintings of Michael Jordan a the admonition "Just Do It."
Sneakers.   Expensive ones.
Who the fuck would buy those?
A car equipped with sub-woofer bass comes booming past. Frank stares at it with the same pained look Bumpy had at the discount emporium.
Your brothers know you're out?
I haven't talked to them in years. It's better that way. For them. I don't know where they are. Went back to Greensboro when they got out, I guess.
Richie nods.    Frank looks back at the new storefronts.
What am I going to do now, be a janitor? What do I know how to do? How am I going to live?
I told you I wouldn't let you starve.
You told me but you can barely take care of yourself.
(glances to a pay phone on the corner) You know, one phone call, Richie, I could be back in business.
The look Richie gives him calmly assures Frank if he did that it'd be the last phone he made outside prison - ever
I won't.   I'm just saying I could.
He buttons the cuffs of the fake Members Only windbreaker Richie bought him off the street.
Thanks for the clothes.
You're welcome.
Frank glances away to three young hoods coming toward the like they own the sidewalk and everything around it - bag pants, bandanas tied around their heads.
Uh-oh. Look out. Here come the gangsters.

Frank's right in their path but doesn't move, forcing one of them to squeeze between him and a parking meter. The gangsta looks back, is about to say something, or do something, but, examining the expression of quiet menace Frank's face, thinks better of it. The others stop.
What.
The first one is still staring at Frank, but finally has good sense to let it go.
Nothing.
They move on.    Frank glances to Richie.
Every idiot gets to be young once.
Frank zips up his Members Only jacket, props up the colla and points himself in the other direction.
Let's get out of here.
